techniques.title: Produce a list of variables to monitor for sustainability impacts
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [2.1 Display any variables that have a negative impact on your project](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#display-any-variables-that-have-a-negative-impact-on-your-project).

description.1: Create a maintainable list of different variables that may impact the sustainability of a product or service over time. By having this list in place, everyone in the creation process can closely monitor the application or website against each variable to determine if an PPP variable present on the list will require resolution either before, during, or after a product or service is launched.
description.2: This list should be created during ideation if possible but can also be machine-generated from a pre-determined list of known PPP factors using evidence and research. The content of this material could be further tested through automation if such variables can be aligned with product capabilities however at a bare minimum, this list must be publicly visible (such as within a sustainability statement) and utilized in-house to enact sustainable change.

examples.1: [The Variables of Website Sustainability](https://websitesustainability.com/cache/files/variables.pdf) provides a comprehensive map of the various carbon traps that exist on the Internet. From business and external elements to development and rendering, it provides a visual representation of the energy usage that can trigger emissions.
examples.2: The [(Proposed) Technology Carbon Standard](https://blog.scottlogic.com/2024/02/13/announcing-the-proposed-technology-carbon-standard.html) is an approach to classify an organization's technology carbon footprint. It is based on the Greenhouse Gas Protocol (GHG) and aligns with Scope 1, 2, and 3 emissions.

procedure.1: Identify all machine-generated variables (hardware/software, etc).
procedure.2: Identify all human-generated variables (business/user, etc).
procedure.3: Create a checklist to be published within sustainability processes.
procedure.4: Circulate among employees as part of the testing workflow.
procedure.5: Check that all variables have been accounted for before publication.
procedure.6: Report the findings within your sustainability statement.

techniques.title: Use quantitative research to measure the needs of users and affected communities
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [2.2 Understand user requirements or constraints, resolving barriers to access](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#understand-user-requirements-or-constraints-resolving-barriers-to-access).

description.1: Provide a mechanism for application and website owners to better curate their products and services around the needs of their users and those affected by what has been created and in doing so, reduce the PPP burden which can impact the sustainability of the website, especially around Social, people-centered (and user experience) impacts.
description.2: It should be noted that for machine automation, only quantitative feedback will be able to be processed (and therefore useful) and all information gathering must be done sustainably and ethically. It should also be noted that because information is being requested, internal access may be required to formally identify certain characteristics necessary for processing.

examples.1: [Quantitative data analysis](https://www.hotjar.com/quantitative-data-analysis/software/) allows you to identify how your website or application is doing, find patterns in user behavior, and make decisions that can benefit your users and optimize your product or service to reduce emissions over time.
examples.2: [Feedback forms](https://www.nngroup.com/articles/user-feedback/) are a great way to get qualitative measurements to reinforce the numbers to ensure that any changes you are considering are wanted, satisfy the needs of users, and meet the sustainability challenge.

procedure.1: Check to see if deliverables require internal access (if so, permission is given).
procedure.2: Gather metrics data through browser APIs, analytics, or third-party software.
procedure.3: Identify resolvable variables that are causing PPP issues.
procedure.4: Once validated as accurate, test further using non-machine testable qualitative methods such as A/B measurement or feedback forms.

techniques.title: Identify user constraints using browser detection and the User-Agent
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [2.2 Understand user requirements or constraints, resolving barriers to access](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#understand-user-requirements-or-constraints-resolving-barriers-to-access).

description.1: Provide a mechanism so that websites and applications can offer contingency processes for users who have constraints such as an older device, an out-of-date operating system, an unusual or out-of-date browser, or a slow Internet connection. Other contingencies exist (such as geo-blocking or mobile data costs) and these can also be taken into account if detection is possible. Each of these issues can burden the user experience and cause added conflict along the pipeline in terms of emissions.
description.2: If detection is not available (such as in cases where the Internet is unavailable), Non-digital investigation should be conducted where possible (such as through the use of mail or telephone feedback). Once the constraint has been detected, it will often be up to the developer to create a solution that will involve compatibility features or reducing the load on the user's device to increase ease of access. If there are questions regarding the potential compatibility or availability of services due to a certain configuration, seek the manufacturer's advice for further guidance.

examples.1: [Using](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Guides/Browser_detection_using_the_user_agent) [UserAgent](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Navigator/userAgent) to identify user characteristics that might impact their experience when using your product or service such as an issue of compatibility or performance.
examples.2: Certain political situations may result in the inability for users to access your product or service hassle-free such as geo-blocking restrictions, the cost of bandwidth, or government-enacted firewalls, filters, or authentication requirements.

procedure.1: Check that all user constraints have been detected.
procedure.2: Ensure that a suitable solution is in place to handle each such event.
procedure.3: Check other contingencies that may affect the availability of your product or service.
procedure.4: Check if a solution can be offered for contingencies, otherwise, try working with partner groups to find solutions.
procedure.5: Check that users can trigger the constrained environment manually.

techniques.title: Test against specific disability profiles for more calibrated accessibility
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [2.2 Understand user requirements or constraints, resolving barriers to access](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#understand-user-requirements-or-constraints-resolving-barriers-to-access).

description.1: Go beyond the remit of WCAG and accessibility by default and to encourage designers and developers of products to test their creations against a range of specific named types of disabilities to both better understand the conditions and to be able to more structurally and sustainably better test for the unique issues each disability brings to technology in terms of adaptation.
description.2: It is strongly encouraged that teams work with individuals with disabilities when attempting this task as they will have the lived experience to help you better adapt your products and services to their needs. If this is not possible or you wish to theorize against certain pre-built profiles, you can refer to established medical texts to identify potential symptoms and refer these against issues that may cause technology issues, building solutions, and/or simulators (see color blindness) to help test for issues along the creation process.

examples.1: The use of a color-blind filter such as the one built into browser DevTools or another [third-party solution](https://github.com/interaktivarum/rgblind?tab=readme-ov-file) potentially helps to identify contrast issues that might not otherwise be detected within an existing website.

procedure.1: Identify users or individuals with disabilities who can help you become more accessible.
procedure.2: Create testable profiles from symptom/issue lists that cause issues.
procedure.3: Check that potential solutions do not interfere with existing functionality.
procedure.4: Create and implement newly calibrated accessibility features.
procedure.5: Check that the features work as implemented against all existing functionality.
procedure.6: Report the findings within your accessibility statement.

techniques.title: Use third-party APIs to measure any passive external impact
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [2.3 Understand the impact for non-users](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#understand-the-impact-for-non-users).

description.1: Utilize the tooling and resources provided by external parties to help you identify any efficiency and sustainability savings when having to use such services, or when non-digital forces come into play, such as if your product or service involves the physical delivery of goods.
description.2: Getting the PPP equation of the sustainability of such forces can be difficult to track, especially as third parties may omit data or not provide a complete picture of their scope emissions. Therefore, care must be taken when choosing providers from the offset and consideration must also be given to the impact of using the API to gather such data together.

examples.1: Using third-party tooling you can [calculate](https://www.cocooncarbon.co.uk/) the carbon emissions from logistics and delivery of physical shipping which can be integrated into your calculations. They also have a [public API](https://developer.cocoonfms.co.uk/) you can use as well.
examples.2: Non-users who are affected by a service can be identified by technical support teams and responses required are added to a list for the developers to machine test for compliance at the next release version.

procedure.1: Identify providers who will offer transparent PPP measurements.
procedure.2: Check the impact of utilization of third-party APIs (if possible).
procedure.3: Check the impact of non-users or passive users affected by your service.
procedure.4: Check that impacted users are accounted for in compliance checks.
procedure.5: Report the findings within your sustainability statement.

techniques.title: Measure interaction cost to reach every page in the information architecture
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [2.6 Minimize non-essential content, interactivity, or journeys](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#minimize-non-essential-content-interactivity-or-journeys).

description.1: Reduce the cognitive load for users between the initial visit to a website or application and reaching their final destination where the information they are seeking is located. The path to locating such information can be routed through multiple interactions such as a search mechanism, hyperlinks, form controls (where appropriate), and progressive disclosure features (reducing the complexity involved in reaching a destination will reduce the rendering load leading to sustainability benefits).
description.2: While there is no hard and fast rule regarding the number of clicks required to meet a user's expectations, including clear way-finding (breadcrumbs can be machine-identified as can landing page regions to guide users along the path). It is therefore a sensible precaution to ensure that the steps required are well documented to avoid overwhelming a user. If required, click-through testing can be measured to identify bottlenecks in complex applications.

examples.1: While the [three-click rule](https://www.nngroup.com/articles/3-click-rule/) is a false heuristic, employing common navigation patterns within a header or footer can help users traverse a product when multiple click-throughs are necessary to reach a destination faster.
examples.2: In complex websites, where multiple levels of documents and potentially thousands of pages may exist, [having breadcrumbs](https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/navigation-breadcrumbs) so that users can track their progress through the layers of a system (and even having dropdown navigation menus through each layer) can help with navigating the information architecture of a product or service with fewer barriers to access.

procedure.1: Check that the information architecture has been designed with clarity in mind.
procedure.2: Check the page for identifiable way-finding processes along a route such as breadcrumbs and landing regions/page patterns.
procedure.3: Check that the number of choices for each action does not exceed a set amount.
procedure.4: Check that every action is well documented and that the expected action occurs.
procedure.5: Check the user flow path for achieving set goals and optimize with shortcuts if necessary.

techniques.title: Check for Content Obscuring Materials That Occur Upon pageLoad
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [2.6 Minimize non-essential content, interactivity, or journeys](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#minimize-non-essential-content-interactivity-or-journeys).

description.1: Ensure that users can read the materials produced for your website or application and click on interactive content (such as links or buttons) that would otherwise be impaired by other content that due to positioning obscures the material by preventing the page from functioning correctly (wasted clicks, especially if JavaScript functions monitor them could lead to emission costs so its best to avoid unnecessary actions).
description.2: There will be occasions when content should be obscured to progressively disclose additional content, but for unintentional overlapping, obscuring deliberately for attention (unnecessary), and all cases where the user did not ask to be impacted, the visibility of the content should be assured (either manually or mechanically through identifying object locations and dimensions plus where conflicts arise, issue remedial advice).

examples.1: Advertising is often a cause of content that temporarily overlaps content with the intent of requesting clicks or attention-grabbing to monetize the material on the website or application. While such actions may be financially reasoned, they are rarely sustainably minded.
examples.2: Consent managers are an example of obscuring materials for the good as they ensure that users to the page authorize potentially invasive technologies before they become active. An example of this is the cookie consent banner that asks for their allowance before they can be used to store sensitive information on the user's machine.
examples.3: Scrollable content in which the scrollbar has been obscured, replaced (with a non-functional, obscured, or hidden replacement), or hidden entirely making it impossible to detect where additional content may occur beyond just the window (such as in overflowing boxes) will be unavailable to users making its use of hardware to render a waste of resources.

procedure.1: Check the page's content to ensure none is clipped by other materials or an overflow issue (with a scrollbar lacking).
procedure.2: Check that all links and buttons are functioning.
procedure.3: Check that progressive disclosing content only appears when requested.
procedure.4: Check that necessary disclosing materials that obscure content can be easily removed.

techniques.title: Break large pieces of content down using progressive disclosure
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [2.6 Minimize non-essential content, interactivity, or journeys](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#minimize-non-essential-content-interactivity-or-journeys).

description.1: Help increase the readability of content within a website or application by breaking down larger pieces of content into smaller constituent pieces. In the same way that a book is broken down into chapters, using progressive disclosure you can reveal sections when the reader is ready, avoiding information overload (the same can be done with long tasks).
description.2: For machine testability, identification of such progressive disclosure markers can be found using the HTML details or dialog element, the CSS target selector (and its accompanying HTML ID attributes), the CSS checkbox hack, the use of JavaScript HashBangs, and also the use of state (and content) changes through various frameworks. Each of these can build a picture of how content displays on-screen during the user experience, and some can load content only when it is requested which can reduce data transfer and rendering requests leading to sustainability improvements.

examples.1: Tabs can be a simple way in which [you can showcase](https://www.gov.uk/bank-holidays) different pieces of information to an audience. By using a mechanism such as the CSS target selector you can reveal information based on its related HTML ID.
examples.2: Dropdown menus such as the one you will find on many websites disclose from a single link several additional roadmapped locations which are grouped children in the information architecture of the product or service.

procedure.1: Check that progressive disclosure is used appropriately with your content or tasks to perform.
procedure.2: Check that progress can be made from one disclosure to another.
procedure.3: Check that each disclosure element can be closed successfully.
procedure.4: Check that the disclosure method you use is compatible with user's browsers.

techniques.title: Remove any non-user initiated pop-up or model windows
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [2.6 Minimize non-essential content, interactivity, or journeys](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#minimize-non-essential-content-interactivity-or-journeys).

description.1: Reduce problematic friction within the user experience and help reduce the number of deceptive patterns which might occur onLoad and during the interaction process as these can cause considerable sustainability issues as a result of wasted emissions. By ensuring that the user remains in control of the interface and that websites and applications work as expected, a more ethical and optimized product or service is likely to result.
description.2: Machine testing can analyze JavaScript for the use of popup events, the appearance of "_blank" within hyperlinks or frames, or other functionality that exists that may produce overlays. It is important to question the acceptability of such usage for example, opening links in new windows may be acceptable for non-web formats like PDF, otherwise, it is best to advise against its use.

examples.1: While not as common today, popup advertisements which appear in a new window or in a separate frame used to be a fixture of the early web and required heavy user management to close multiple banners that would trigger.

procedure.1: Check for CSS and JavaScript overlays that may occur onLoad and remove when identified.
procedure.2: Check that any popup events can only be initiated with the user's consent.
procedure.3: Check all hyperlinks for new window opening triggers (and action as appropriate).

techniques.title: Decorative design elements can be disabled if they are not done so by default
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [2.7 Use decorative design with care](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#use-decorative-design-with-care).

description.1: Provide a mechanism in which users can reduce their impact by choosing to have a more basic experience (to what extent will be up to the developer) by downloading fewer external resources, scripts, and other assets to their machine to be processed and rendered. With this action, a website or application that is already optimized for sustainability can go one step further in providing a barebones format for those wishing to prioritize lowering their footprint over having added functionality.
description.2: This action could be performed by defining what assets have been added to the product or service to enhance the experience but are not of critical importance (such as background images, or decorative flourishes that can be machine identified). Other forms of decoration can also be machine-identified such as CSS flourishes to content and images, background sounds, custom cursors, custom scrollbars, etc.

examples.1: Web browsers can [change CSS cursors](https://csscursor.info/), and while there may be functional reasons to do so under certain circumstances, such as to indicate loading progress, zoom, or click-ability, in most circumstances, you should leave it at the system default as this is the expected behavior.
examples.2: CSS scrollbars [can be customized](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/CSS_scrollbars_styling) or replaced but this can be problematic for users. Changes in scroll speed or its mechanics can affect impact readability and the way things render, and color changes can impact visibility and affect overflow regions within elements of the page. In such cases, the system default always functions better than a custom solution.

procedure.1: Check decorative images are clearly labeled using ARIA so assistive technologies can skip them.
procedure.2: Check that CSS decoration can be disabled if it may interfere with readability.
procedure.3: Check that custom scrollbars and cursors can be disabled as they may interfere with a user's ability to interact with the screen.
procedure.4: Check that background sounds can be disabled and do not auto-load or auto-play.
procedure.5: Check that decorative features can be disabled at the user's request.

techniques.title: Making your navigation menu accessible and well-structured
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [2.8 Ensure that navigation and wayfinding are well-structured](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#ensure-that-navigation-and-wayfinding-are-well-structured).

description.1: Verify that your navigation menu is crafted in such a manner that it is both accessible to users and user-agents and functions correctly so that when implemented it does not lead to issues when attempting to browse the information architecture of a website or application. If the information architecture were to fail, this would lead to PPP failings as your users would no longer be able to use the product or service without encountering barriers to access and risk further emissions attempting to solve the issue.
description.2: Machine testing the structure of a navigation menu will usually involve the nav, ul, or ol elements within the header of a product or service which repeats across pages and assuming that links function as expected and click ratios (sizes) are large enough on both desktop and mobile platforms, any search functionality will also need to be tested to ensure that results are provided upon submission.

examples.1: The hamburger design is often considered the stereotype of [mobile functionality](https://www.smashingmagazine.com/2022/11/navigation-design-mobile-ux/), a three-lined icon that represents a menu upon clicking it reveals a full-screen list of options. Employing good patterns is key to reducing confusion and abandonment from users

procedure.1: Check that the structure of the navigation menu is semantically correct.
procedure.2: Check that the structure of the navigation menu is repeated across all pages.
procedure.3: Check that the click sizes/ratios of anchors in navigation menus are large enough on both mobile and desktop to be comfortable.
procedure.4: Check that the URLs provided within links do not lead to errors.
procedure.5: Check that any search functionality provides results (not errors) upon submission.

techniques.title: Provide a human-readable sitemap to improve the information architecture
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [2.8 Ensure that navigation and wayfinding are well-structured](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#ensure-that-navigation-and-wayfinding-are-well-structured).

description.1: Increase the findability of the content within your website among search engines and social networks. By creating a XML sitemap in the base directory of your website, and potentially having a human-readable) HTML sitemap to supplement it, you provide an index of all the publicly available pages. This acts as a potential signpost for individuals who may find themselves seeking information but not knowing exactly where it is stored.
description.2: When creating an HTML sitemap it will be important to categorize pages into lists based on what section of the website they appear in (for human readability) rather than providing everything in a single long list. Structurally, you could use lists within lists to provide this distinction or use subheadings with individual lists. Both methods should ensure to be semantically correct and accessible to meet the human requirements of PPP targets.

examples.1: The [Sitemaps protocol](https://www.sitemaps.org/protocol.html) showcases a basic XML sitemap format that can be used within the base directory of a website. It is supported by search engines like Google and can be submitted for indexing which can increase findability and potentially help users find your product or service quicker.
examples.2: An [HTML sitemap](https://www.semrush.com/blog/html-sitemap/) is a more visually organized showcase of the pages publicly available within your product or service. The idea behind it is to be as comprehensive as possible but not to overwhelm the user. This might be the ideal place to use a system like progressive disclosure so that you can guide individuals through the materials you provide interactively.

procedure.1: Check for a sitemap.xml file in the base directory of a website.
procedure.2: Check that the markup of the file is semantically correct.
procedure.3: Check that all of the links held within do not produce any errors.
procedure.4: Check for the existence of a publicly visible HTML sitemap.
procedure.5: Check that the file exists alongside a sitemap.xml format.
procedure.6: Check that the HTML sitemap is semantically correct.

techniques.title: Provide a method of keeping up-to-date with product or service updates
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [2.8 Ensure that navigation and wayfinding are well-structured](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#ensure-that-navigation-and-wayfinding-are-well-structured).

description.1: Ensure that users and users of an application or website can monitor changes and events that occur over time. The need to be able to track such events is critical as customers become reliant on products and services. This reliance on such features means that time will have been invested into learning how to set up and use the product, which if it fails could have a sustainability impact not just for the product or service owner, but for those reliant on its ability to function.
description.2: Every product or service will have its own update schedule and there will be no hard and fast rule in terms of how often a website or application should be offering new releases. That being said, there should be a mechanism in place to describe news events both in a syndicated format and on the website, and a system status mechanism to identify any current issues with the product or service.

examples.1: [Apple has a newsroom](https://www.apple.com/newsroom/) that is very minimalistic yet it contains all that you would expect from a news category from a major website. It has grouped stories with useful headlines, dates, categories, and a picture. Having something similar for your website can help users find new material quickly and reduce churn digging through archives.
examples.2: [Syndication feeds](https://www.w3.org/blog/feed/) come in multiple different formats but the most common is the RSS format. They are compatible with readers on every platform and can be a useful way to get news to subscribers quickly. While these make regular requests to websites, they request less data and result in users spending less time browsing overall which is an emissions-positive event.

procedure.1: Check for a news page or category of a website.
procedure.2: Check the news section has been updated within 12 months.
procedure.3: Check for a syndication feed in RSS, Atom, or JSON.
procedure.4: Check the syndication feed has been updated within 12 months.
procedure.5: Check for other syndicated events (podcasts, OPML, etc).
procedure.6: Check the syndication feed is semantically correct.

techniques.title: Request permission for invasive access to interact with content
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [2.9 Design to assist and not to distract](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#design-to-assist-and-not-to-distract).

description.1: Use the least amount of permission requests required to achieve a given task. Allowing the user to control when they receive information is critically important but it is also important not to burden them with requests to access hardware or do things that might prove invasive (such as triggering notifications or a pop-up window).
description.2: For mechanical testability, JavaScript APIs can check using methods such as requestPermission() to identify if a website or application has been granted access to use various hardware or potentially abusable features within the web browser. Unsubscribe, and delete/freeze account links could also be identified (with internal access being granted).

examples.1: Cookie notification messages are required by law (the EU Cookie Directive) and could be identified by a script. These are heavily featured within websites and allow users to prioritize privacy over the availability of functionality assuming that they are implemented correctly.
examples.2: Customizing or removing functionality within applications can help simplify the workflow of a user and increase the productivity within an interface (which will have sustainability benefits as it could reduce the weight from unnecessary features loading and users spending less time at the screen).

procedure.1: Check which permissions from the available APIs are being granted.
procedure.2: Check if products or services have unsubscribe/account freezing and removal options.
procedure.3: Check if cookies are used and if so, if notifications are triggered appropriately (with the option to disable all).
procedure.4: Check if applications plug-in functionality and allow for customization.

techniques.title: Encourage features that help users achieve tasks
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [2.9 Design to assist and not to distract](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#design-to-assist-and-not-to-distract).

description.1: Lower the barriers to entry with content. When dealing with complex, multi-page websites it becomes increasingly important to have features in place to allow users to bypass repeated elements that they have already prefilled to achieve goals quicker (this is a key variable for sites who have large membership numbers).
description.2: There are functional ways to increase the flow through a website and allow users to accomplish a task that can also be machine-testable. This technique is most useful when dealing with complex pieces of content, multi-step products, or services that have a lot of functionality that may require shortcuts to allow faster decision-making under certain conditions.

examples.1: [Read-It-Later](https://goodlinks.app/) software may be provided by third-parties but they allow for both offline access to content on a variety of platforms and customization of the materials visually based on the user's requirements.
examples.2: Quick purchase features (such as Amazon's famous "Buy Now" button) allow for the immediate purchase of a product, skipping past the shopping basket steps and using prior purchase knowledge to reduce friction.
examples.3: Shortcut links and patterns can be used to skip ahead or over information and/or pages when it is recognized that the information may not be relevant or required in a multi-step process (such as form filling).

procedure.1: Check for read-it-later compatibility within articles.
procedure.2: Check for purchasable products and the option to quickly purchase (bonus points if no login is required).
procedure.3: Check if the HTML head contains landmark links of relevance to be identified.
procedure.4: Check for recognized landmark shortcuts (skip links, etc) and that they are functional.

techniques.title: Avoid mechanisms that promote excessive screen time
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [2.9 Design to assist and not to distract](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#design-to-assist-and-not-to-distract).

description.1: Allow the user to achieve the task they initially set out to do and not trigger unnecessary issues in the user experience which would undermine their ability to complete the said task. Issues such as infinite scrolling can promote a need for continued browsing (which can load excessive data and have a sustainability impact on rendering) and loading overlays that deviate users from their path will have wider societal impacts on PPP targets which need to be considered.
description.2: Within this technique, machine testability can be considered by examining if common link pagination landmarks (previous, next, <numbers>, etc) exist within category listings and if overlays or attention-keeping features are detected for common patterns (such as those mentioned in the examples below). If screen addition mechanisms are determined to be in use within a website, this should be considered a failing mark against the related success criteria.

examples.1: Sale promotional overlays are a common theme that displays upon loading a page and requests the user take notice of them before dismissing them to view the content they want to examine.
examples.2: Information request overlays are another model window that often appears during a browsing session such as requesting your email address for a newsletter or your details to encourage sign-up after a timed period.

procedure.1: Check if infinite scrolling is being used through pagination landmark links.
procedure.2: Check for recognized attention-keeping patterns that obscure content.

techniques.title: Build using established design patterns that use known conventions
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [2.10 Use established design patterns and appropriate components](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#use-established-design-patterns-and-appropriate-components).

description.1: Use repeating patterns that users are likely to recognize from visits to other websites to build a sense of comfort and identification with your products and services. By using established design patterns that are repeatable, recognizable, and testable, you can reduce the amount of confusion likely to occur within a user-interface and this will increase the speed of adaptability (which has sustainability benefits).
description.2: It should be noted that for machine testability, heuristic recognition (identification of patterns in code) will likely allow product creators to recognize the implementation of certain patterns, especially when libraries or design systems are utilized as the backbone of a product or service. Through this, recommendations can be made to improve layouts.

examples.1: A website layout could follow a [conventional design pattern](https://htmlburger.com/blog/website-layout-ideas/) aimed at a recognized reading flow such as the F or Z pattern. They are based on established scientific studies of how people first identify and then read content on a screen. The mechanics behind such layouts are designed using CSS and can be identified based on the grid or flexbox pattern used to reduce the time users spend scanning the screen.
examples.2: [Individual components](https://ui-patterns.com/patterns) that aim to be repeatable conventions across products and services can take many forms (some are often provided as third-party services due to the build complexity involved) and should aim to be visually recognizable even if stylistic differences occur for branding which will help reduce wasted screen time.

procedure.1: Check for common in-page design patterns or libraries.
procedure.2: Verify page components and overall design against established conventions.
procedure.3: Check for and implement solutions for layout flow issues that could be optimized using an established pattern.

techniques.title: Eliminate deceptive design patterns or manipulative techniques
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [2.11 Avoid being manipulative or deceptive](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#avoid-being-manipulative-or-deceptive).

description.1: Prevent the user from being manipulated being a recognized dark pattern that falls under the umbrella of deceptive design. While there are a large number of ways to code ethically, using any one of these named practices would constitute a failure against WSG guidelines and as such, ensuring that practices are not used is worthy of inclusion.
description.2: Machine testability for deceptive patterns will vary based on the type in use however the potential to integrate artificial intelligence to assist with more subtle uses of manipulation within tooling could be used. More obvious issues derided from code injection can be flagged and reported as problematic.

examples.1: Disabling interface functionality such as the ability to highlight/select the text, right-click on content, copy the content to the clipboard, print, or paste passwords from management software can cause significant problematic friction.

procedure.1: Check for bad practices such as those mentioned in the examples.
procedure.2: Check against a library of [deceptive design](https://www.deceptive.design/) patterns.

techniques.title: Determine if analytics can be sustainably improved or removed
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [2.11 Avoid being manipulative or deceptive](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#avoid-being-manipulative-or-deceptive).

description.1: Eliminate the PPP human (third-party emissions, privacy, and performance) issues that relate to the use of analytics software. While this technique does not advocate that such software needs to be removed in all instances, the potential to flag poor-performing options and recommend more optimized solutions (or request removal) will be recommended.
description.2: This should take into consideration the need for analytics in other success criteria (for research metrics) before recommending removal and identifying low-carbon options for third-party solutions (where data exists). Additional criteria based on PPP values (such as privacy and security) should also be considered.

examples.1: Some [analytics providers](https://bejamas.com/blog/best-ga4-alternatives-for-2023) have made steps to become more sustainable which would potentially make them a better replacement for bulkier, more intrusive packages.

procedure.1: Check to determine if an analytics script is being used within the page.
procedure.2: Check against a list of suppliers of software to determine viable alternatives.
procedure.3: Check to determine if data being gathered complies with GDPR and other privacy legislation.
procedure.4: If no viable alternative exists and it still performs poorly, recommend removal.

techniques.title: Eliminate any manipulative SEO techniques from your source code
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [2.11 Avoid being manipulative or deceptive](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#avoid-being-manipulative-or-deceptive).

description.1: Proof your code and content for practices that might detract from the user experience but are done, purely in an attempt to gain higher rankings from within search engines. While getting such a position would be beneficial, using such techniques will often get the reputation of your site on these services tarnished and your rank will suffer significantly.
description.2: Your visibility in search engines and social media matters. Visibility is how people find you on the web. If people cannot find you or sections of your website or application, they will consume resources in that effort (or trying to find a replacement). Additionally, bad SEO practices targeting only machines consume user resources for rendering and produce excess emissions.

examples.1: Keyword stuffing is a practice in which the terms you want to be recognized for get repeated throughout your documents. While mentioning it occasionally is good, going over the top can hurt readability and bloat pages further, which is why it is not considered sustainable.
examples.2: Hiding content, for example, using small font sizes, making the text the same color as the background, hiding text behind images, or generating CSS or JavaScript content purely for search engines is considered bad practice.

procedure.1: Check for the keywords META tag and recommend its removal.
procedure.2: Check for the refresh META tag and recommend replacement with a page redirect header.
procedure.3: Check for hidden content as identified in the above example and promote visibility or removal.
procedure.4: Check for duplicate content and flag it for removal.

techniques.title: Provide deliverables in reusable, self-isolated components
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [2.12 Make deliverables understandable and reusable](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#make-deliverables-understandable-and-reusable).

description.1: Allow for code that has been produced for an individual project to be re-used and reapplied across future work to reduce redundancy. This is most commonly seen in frameworks and libraries but is not limited as such and can also apply to documentation and snippets.
description.2: This technique is most useful when it is housed within an open source location to foster a culture of contribution, remixing, and improving of the work. While machine testing of code to determine functionality based on its apparent need would prove problematic, the ability to use importable code can be verified.

examples.1: A library like [Bootstrap](https://getbootstrap.com/) can be imported as a whole into a project, but it can also be stripped back, eliminating all but the components that are in use by the website or application powering its functionality.

procedure.1: Check to see if deliverables require internal access (if so, permission is given).
procedure.2: Check to determine if these deliverables are housed in an open source environment.
procedure.3: Check projects for multiple CSS files (or use of @imports).
procedure.4: Check JavaScript for the use of imports or self-isolating functions.
procedure.5: Check documentation for section separation as markdown files.

techniques.title: Provide documentation to guide the deliverables
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [2.12 Make deliverables understandable and reusable](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#make-deliverables-understandable-and-reusable).

description.1: Guarantee that those without a working knowledge of an aspect of design or development will be provided with the information they require so that they can safely work with the files being presented to them during the creation and maintenance process.
description.2: Because emissions do not start or stop at website usage, and emissions are created during the ideation and creation process, it is crucial that all involved with the project, even clients who may not be used to the types of technology to which this specification refers to, can optimize their ability to produce high-quality output, as this will reflect in sustainable websites and applications.

examples.1: Many large projects have manuals or documentation that describe in detail how to work with the creations of a group of people either during the handoff (from one department to another) stage or during the completion (from the creators to the clients) stage.

procedure.1: Check to see if deliverables require internal access (if so, permission is given).
procedure.2: Check that the instructions, manual, or documentation exist.
procedure.3: If the documentation does not exist, flag a request to produce materials.
procedure.4: Check for multiple format types such as HTML, PDF, checklists, slideshow, and video.

techniques.title: Create code comments to describe the functionality of features
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [2.12 Make deliverables understandable and reusable](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#make-deliverables-understandable-and-reusable).

description.1: Provide internal or external developers with the information they require to understand the justification behind certain coding choices, and what individual pieces of code exist for. While such features can be itemized within the documentation, code comments are useful for providing a portable library of notes with the source code itself.
description.2: Every language will have its own descriptive mechanism for producing code comments and developers should prescribe to such best practices. Conventions could be utilized within comments such as including links to provide added context. Comments can be machine-detected by their opening and closing statements and paired with the code that follows them.

examples.1: In the source code for [Semantic Web Hook](https://swhook.com/), code comments are available for the un-minimized version to help developers identify the purpose behind each function (so they can decide if they require it).

procedure.1: Check for code comments within the source code of pages.
procedure.2: Check the formatting of comments for conventions such as links, images, and bullets.
procedure.3: If publicly facing, flag it for removal, if internal access is required or a developer release, keep it in place.

techniques.title: Implement an up-to-date design system
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [2.13 Use a design system for interface consistency](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#use-a-design-system-for-interface-consistency).

description.1: Ensure that stylistic choices made by the design and development team are based upon prescribed defaults. This will encourage consistency not just within the layout but also in terms of writing style, accessibility, sustainability, and other variables being monitored.
description.2: There are already several established [design systems](https://designsystemsrepo.com/design-systems/), which provide a [good baseline](https://uxdesign.cc/everything-you-need-to-know-about-design-systems-54b109851969) for what should should be included within them. Either deploy an existing open source solution or craft a custom model that meets the needs of your product or service. Machine testability will rely on identifying the design system and then verifying the materials are being used in the wild.

examples.1: [Atlassian Design System](https://atlassian.design/) breaks its library down visually on the main page to give new readers a great roadmap for where reusable components can be located and how everything should be represented.
examples.2: [Carbon Design System](https://carbondesignsystem.com/) provides dropdown menus of its entire library of components to allow users to quickly and easily access the elements they require, with a firm focus on being an open source project.

procedure.1: Check for the implementation of a design system.
procedure.2: Check what number of categories being monitored.
procedure.3: Check if the patterns and tokens are being employed.
procedure.4: Check when the design system was last updated.

techniques.title: Increase the readability of content using common metrics
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [2.14 Provide clear, inclusive content with purpose](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#provide-clear-inclusive-content-with-purpose).

description.1: Make the content within your website or application more legible to individuals who may struggle with more technical language. Techniques such as lowering the reading age, removing industry terms (or clearly defining them), and having translations for international audiences can help get your message across.
description.2: This technique is most useful when dealing with a large body of content that the user has to wade through to complete a task. Being able to reduce screen time by improving the ease at which users can comprehend a topic will ultimately allow for an experience that feels faster and discriminates less against individuals who may struggle with highly technical content.

examples.1: [Transport for London](https://tfl.gov.uk/info-for/suppliers-and-contractors/digital-design-toolkit/using-plain-english) has an editorial style guide that sets out to use Plain English throughout their website. The guide itself serves as a useful tool that others could adapt (including the terms in machine testability).
examples.2: There are lots of technical terms used in (for example) the web industry, Jens Oliver Meiert has created the [Web Glossary](https://webglossary.info/) as a dictionary of terminology which can help clarify confusing terminology.
examples.3: [Readability Formulas](https://readabilityformulas.com/readability-scoring-system.php) have an assessment tool that can use one of several different models to identify issues with content. As there is no agreed-upon assessment model, this can be particularly helpful.

procedure.1: Check against a list of terms for the use of Plain English.
procedure.2: Check that terminology is inclusive and non-discriminatory.
procedure.3: Check that technical terms are identified and well-defined.
procedure.4: Check that the content has an appropriate reading age.
procedure.5: Check for internationalization within content, HTML, and CSS.

techniques.title: Break long-form content down into a simpler structure
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [2.14 Provide clear, inclusive content with purpose](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#provide-clear-inclusive-content-with-purpose).

description.1: Avoid users being hit with a wall of text which risks abandonment of the page (and a wasted session with emissions attached). By taking large pieces of information and structuring them into more clean smaller chunks and utilizing a range of more friendlier features when appropriate such as lists and tables, the information will look less intimidating.
description.2: For machine testability, identifying clear headings, visual hierarchy, spacing, line breaks, lists, use of images, and other features of HTML can help calculate the relative density of the content and whether it could be better presented not just for readers but to (if used with progressive disclosure) reduce the initial impact on rendering engines which can have a sustainable impact on hardware.

examples.1: This article from [Nielson Norman Group](https://www.nngroup.com/articles/formatting-long-form-content/) provides some great examples and ideas around the subject of dealing with long-form content on the web, each of which can be both implemented and tested against.

procedure.1: Check that the heading hierarchy structure is correct (H1 > H6).
procedure.2: Check that paragraphs do not exceed a set word length.
procedure.3: Check the spacing between elements is not too crowded.

techniques.title: Produce a list of SEO considerations to improve your findability
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [2.14 Provide clear, inclusive content with purpose](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#provide-clear-inclusive-content-with-purpose).

description.1: Reduce the amount of time users and potential users spend churning through data attempting to locate you (or pages relating to you) through search engines or social media. These types of requests have an emissions impact from the hardware used to deal with the requests to the rendering of the results, therefore getting the right information to users as quickly as possible is critical to having a sustainable product.
description.2: This list should be created as early as possible but could be machine-generated from a pre-determined list of SEO variables. The content of this material could be machine-tested against using automation if the variables can be aligned with what has been implemented. Additionally, publicly-facing social media handles that are identified within a product or service website can be detected.

examples.1: [SEMRush](https://www.semrush.com/blog/seo-checklist/) has produced a checklist of SEO considerations which is based on their years of industry experience. While not everything will be able to be tested against, it is good to consider to improve overall visibility.
examples.2: [AHREFs](https://ahrefs.com/blog/seo-checklist/) have created a checklist that contains a lot of advice and tips on SEO. This list also has some components which are not testable but the advice could also lead to sustainability benefits as a side-effect.

procedure.1: Check against an SEO checklist for the state of a product or service's visibility (internal access may be required).
procedure.2: Check for the website or application's position in major search engines.
procedure.3: Check for social media handles and when they were last used.

techniques.title: Implement a range of images of the appropriate format and size
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [2.15 Optimize images for sustainability](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#optimize-images-for-sustainability).

description.1: Identify whether the images you are using are firstly necessary (which may be difficult to machine test), and secondly are using a format that is web appropriate. While these considerations may seem small they can dramatically lead to performance benefits that can reduce loading times and page bloat (which is an increasing issue on today's Internet).
description.2: Implementations should consider in necessity the total image count (too many over a certain ratio could be problematic for those with bandwidth limits). Machine testability for web graphics can easily detect older formats that should be replaced immediately, formats that could potentially be changed for optimization purposes, and formats that could become vector graphics.

examples.1: Certain image formats perform better than others, AVIF and WebP will (in most cases) have better optimization rates than the original three classics for the web (PNG, JPEG, and GIF) and should be considered by default.
examples.2: Different devices have different breakpoints, but these should not be used as hard and fast rules for every situation as there are far too many devices out there to be compatible with. It makes better sense (if serving a single image) to default to the mid-range of the average device you receive.

procedure.1: Check the image density of the page and flag pages over a certain image count.
procedure.2: Check for older image format usage (BMP/TIFF) and require replacement.
procedure.3: Check for PNG and JPEG images and flag potential upgrades to AVIF or WebP.
procedure.4: Provide fallbacks using the picture element on newer image formats to ensure compatibility.
procedure.5: Check for GIF and flag static image upgrade to AVIF or WebP, or animated images to mp4.

techniques.title: Optimizing all image assets for a variety of different resolutions
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [2.15 Optimize images for sustainability](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#optimize-images-for-sustainability).

description.1: Ensure that images are not only served at the correct resolution and size for the device requesting them but also to make sure that the images being served have been compressed using a suitable algorithm to provide the asset at the lowest bandwidth requirements possible to the user, thereby improving multiple PPP variables and increasing performance.
description.2: Compression tests can be run against every image to see if improvements can be made (above and beyond changing formats) without losing too much image quality that visibility becomes degraded and therefore a recognition issue. The use of the sizes attribute can also help provide alternative images for different resolutions as required by device requirements (though the default image should be set to a median value to balance size and weight).

examples.1: [DebugBear](https://www.debugbear.com/blog/responsive-images) showcases how responsive images can be used to provide not just different optimized formats (for better compression) but different sizes to reduce the performance load on user's machines.
examples.2: MDN has a section on [responsive images](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTML/Guides/Responsive_images) that goes into detail (with examples) showcasing how they can be created to work well across a variety of different platforms using the HTML IMG element.

procedure.1: Check for [compression potential](https://webspeedtest.cloudinary.com/) against every available image asset.
procedure.2: Check CSS media or container queries to recreate different breakpoints in the design to identify and create the sizes of images required.
procedure.3: Check for the use of the sizes attribute to provide responsive images.
procedure.4: Provide optimized solutions if image problems have been detected.
procedure.5: Check that the default image value is set to a median value.

techniques.title: Include lazy-loading with images that load below-the-fold
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [2.15 Optimize images for sustainability](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#optimize-images-for-sustainability).

description.1: Prevent image assets included within a website or application that are either visually below the fold or hidden due to progressive disclosure from being loaded until they appear in view of the user's screen. This can save bandwidth and the resulting processing of the image at the client-side which otherwise would occur and may not even be used if the user chooses to click elsewhere or close before reaching it.
description.2: While it is preferable that only links below the fold have HTML lazy-loading attributes attached to them, there does not appear to be a penalty for including it within all images so if machine testing cannot differentiate this should not be discriminated against as a failing point. Additionally, the point of the fold can change based on the type of device being used so it is worth considering this into processes.

examples.1: [Mathias Bynens](https://mathiasbynens.be/demo/img-loading-lazy) created a [lazy-loading](https://web.dev/articles/browser-level-image-lazy-loading?hl=en) demonstration that showcases the technique being used in the wild. As you scroll down the page of the website, more of the images will be loaded on demand.

procedure.1: Check for the position of the fold on the smallest screen size users use.
procedure.2: Check for HTML lazy loading attributes against all images falling outside these dimensions.
procedure.3: Check for HTML lazy loading attributes against all images in progressive disclosure boxes.

techniques.title: Provide the option for images to be disabled or a low fidelity alternative
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [2.15 Optimize images for sustainability](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#optimize-images-for-sustainability).

description.1: Ensure that users with bandwidth restrictions or slow connections are given a mechanism to access your content when their ability to access critical information may be stressed. Providing such options may include an in-page solution (either by default or by choice), or through the offering of a highly optimized alternative for such requests.
description.2: When providing such requests through a secondary stream (such as a low-fidelity option), this channel must not become as bloated as the primary channel. As such, guidelines should be drawn up regarding what can and cannot be included to ensure limitations are placed to maintain a basic level of service while not offering the full capability of the primary product.

examples.1: [NPR provides a text-only version](https://text.npr.org/) of their main website to offer a basic level of service for those who may wish to access their services but have limitations on what they can access. As such, everything has been stripped back providing no interactivity, features, or other distractions.
examples.2: [CNN provides a lightweight version](https://lite.cnn.com/) of their website which does request cookie permissions (for analytics?) but the content is free of images, videos, and other components that can be render-blocking.

procedure.1: Check if an in-page "Lo-Fi" or "Eco mode" option exists, if by choice, recommend by default.
procedure.2: Check for a low-fidelity/text-only/lightweight subdomain or path.
procedure.3: Check that the low-fidelity option is an agreed upon percentage lighter than the main website.

techniques.title: Add details about image impacts to the media management and use policy
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [2.15 Optimize images for sustainability](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#optimize-images-for-sustainability).

description.1: Ensure that you provide details about any image reduction targets and techniques within a publicly available media management and use policy. This will help you to establish the criteria you will attempt to meet across your product or service and allow users to identify any failings if they spot them (which can be fixed during the product lifecycle).
description.2: Machine testability for such processes can involve first ensuring that the media management and use policy exists and then checking for a section on images that exists can be a definable way of identifying that the subject is being mentioned. Content can be checked for accuracy through auditing processes and failings flagged up as issues requiring resolution to maintain compliance.

examples.1: [Sprout Social](https://sproutsocial.com/insights/social-media-policy/) has a toolkit that guides you through the creation of a social media policy, which could easily be adapted to include ethics and PPP factors like sustainability within its criteria (under legal guidelines).

procedure.1: Check for media management and use policy existence.
procedure.2: Check for a section on images to verify impact coverage.

techniques.title: Remove any functionality that may trigger auto-playing animation
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [2.16 Optimize media for sustainability](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#optimize-media-for-sustainability).

description.1: Ensure that media will only run within a website or application on the command of the user and not begin consuming resources and thrashing hardware from the immediacy of the page load event. Because this involves HTML (attributes and background media), JavaScript, and images (animated GIFs), a multi-functional approach is required.
description.2: Because media can involve audio and video, implementors will need to ensure that both are treated with equal respect as they both consume resources and contribute to emissions (to varying degrees). Additional care will also need to be taken to identify background media and prevent its sudden onset unless the function of that page or application is to show a media file (with nothing else).

examples.1: Advertisements are one of the most common forms of autoplaying media, they often appear as small boxes ([Wired is an example of this in use](https://www.wired.com/story/how-to-turn-off-autoplay-in-browser/)). While muting the media may reduce noise pollution, it does not reduce the carbon impact of loading, rendering, and playing of the media itself.

procedure.1: Check for background media and prevent auto-playing upon page load.
procedure.2: Check that media that is required to play as a function of the product is muted by default.
procedure.3: Check for audio and video HTML elements and remove any autoplay true events.
procedure.4: Check for custom audio or video players and flag auto-playing media.

techniques.title: Optimizing all audio and video assets for speed and compatibility
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [2.16 Optimize media for sustainability](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#optimize-media-for-sustainability).

description.1: Ensure that both the formats being used for media have widespread browser compatibility and that the audio and video being served have been compressed using a suitable algorithm to provide the asset at the lowest bandwidth requirements possible to the user, thereby improving multiple PPP variables and increasing performance.
description.2: Compression tests can be run against every video and audio file to see if improvements can be made without losing too much quality that the artifact becomes degraded beyond usefulness. Audio and video formats to be embedded with browser compatibility issues can also be machine detected and recommendations for alternatives can be offered (and implemented).

examples.1: [BBC iPlayer](https://www.bbc.co.uk/iplayer) is an on-demand platform that can change the quality setting of the video being streamed. The quality being applied also changes based on variables impacting the environment.
examples.2: [YouTube](https://www.youtube.com/) has a setting to alter the streaming quality of videos (where the quality can be lowered). Again this platform uses browser metrics to automatically adjust the stream quality based on the user's environment.

procedure.1: Check for compression potential against every available audio and video asset.
procedure.2: Provide optimized solutions if audio or video problems have been detected.
procedure.3: Check for third-party non-native media player usage and recommend native options (if possible).

techniques.title: Provide facades for media, animated GIFs, and third-party content
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [2.16 Optimize media for sustainability](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#optimize-media-for-sustainability).

description.1: Provide a mechanism that ensures users remain in control of when highly impactful (in terms of emissions) media or third-party materials begin to transmit to their devices. By having a static facade that upon clicking begins the render (and not simply hiding the video, audio or interactive element behind the static image), you ensure that the content has a lazy-load effect even if autoplay or the interaction is not active (as pre-buffering may occur during the render process).
description.2: Because there is no browser default method for facades (at the time of publication), identification of such events for machine testability will come down to them being clearly labeled using ID or class attributes (or through heuristic testing for an image that is either anchor linked or has a button attached with a JavaScript event handler to process the content switch).

examples.1: Jason Knight has provided some [simple but useful examples](https://codepen.io/jason-knight/pen/OJBjgNQ) of his own implementation of accessible HTML video facades which he developed as a solution to the performance (and sustainability) issues media can cause.

procedure.1: Check that no video or audio elements trigger content upon the page load.
procedure.2: Check that any uses of the GIF extension are not animated by default.
procedure.3: Check that no impactful third-party content activate upon the page load.

techniques.title: Optimizing all media assets for a variety of different resolutions
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [2.16 Optimize media for sustainability](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#optimize-media-for-sustainability).

description.1: Ensure that videos are not only served at the correct resolution but also to identify assets that can help users make decisions before choosing to load the main video as to whether the media is correct for them. The location of these links should be connected to the embedded media, and either replace the original video upon click or downloadable for the user (they should not increase the number of embeds).
description.2: JavaScript can be used to detect the resolution of the device accessing the media and serve the correct media size for the user requesting it (ensuring smaller devices do not get larger media files). Regarding the types of links to be offered, they should provide the user with more choice in terms of the quality of the video being consumed or provide added context to its purpose.

examples.1: The [Internet Archive](https://archive.org/) provides downloadable media files in a variety of formats in addition to being able to stream. This helps reduce the repeat burden on servers and avoids page-reload rendering emissions.

procedure.1: Check that the video assets are provided in a variety of common resolutions (which can be user-chosen).
procedure.2: Check for automatic detection and selection of media resolutions.
procedure.3: Check if clips or trailers are provided to give a shorter overview.
procedure.4: Check if downloads are provided for repeat viewing.

techniques.title: Add details about media impacts to the media management and use policy
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [2.16 Optimize media for sustainability](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#optimize-media-for-sustainability).

description.1: Ensure that you provide details about any audio or video reduction targets and techniques within a publicly available media management and use policy. This will help you to establish the criteria you will attempt to meet across your product or service and allow users to identify any failings if they spot them (which can be fixed during the product lifecycle).
description.2: Machine testability for such processes can involve first ensuring that the media management and use policy exists and then checking for a section on audio, video, or media, exists can be a definable way of identifying that the subject is being mentioned. Content can be checked for accuracy through auditing processes and failings flagged up as issues requiring resolution to maintain compliance.

examples.1: [HootSuite](https://blog.hootsuite.com/social-media-policy-for-employees/) has a template that guides you through the creation of a social media policy, which could easily be adapted to include ethics and PPP factors like sustainability within its criteria (under a new section).

procedure.1: Check for media management and use policy existence.
procedure.2: Check for a section on audio to verify impact coverage.
procedure.3: Check for a section on video to verify impact coverage.
procedure.4: Check for a section on media if the above does not exist to verify impact coverage.

techniques.title: Measure and respond to high-intensity animation usage
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [2.17 Ensure animation is proportionate and easy to control](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#ensure-animation-is-proportionate-and-easy-to-control).

description.1: Determine if animation usage within an application or website will diminish the user experience. By calculating the number of animations that occur and identifying if this number firstly can be reduced and then running each of them individually and identifying if they cause lagging on lower specification devices, offering a resolution will help reduce the CPU and GPU burden which can consume vast user resources.
description.2: It should be noted that the types of animations used can dramatically affect the rendering process. Certain CSS transitions and animations are more process efficient than others, and JavaScript animation can also have differing impacts on CSS in both the choice of animation and how it has been put together. This should be considered when testing to offer low-impact animations and effects.

examples.1: Personal portfolios are an ideal place to showcase expertise and you have more liberty to experiment with technologies including animation, which is precisely what [Kent C. Dodds](https://kentcdodds.com/), [Sarah Drasner](https://sarah.dev/), and [Una Kravetz](https://una.im/) have done.

procedure.1: Check both CSS and JavaScript for animations and calculate the number that exists.
procedure.2: If too many (based on a justified value) exist, request the removal of the most impactful.
procedure.3: Check if animation techniques can be replaced by more efficient methods.
procedure.4: Check individual animations to determine if the CPU or GPU burden on devices is within safe limits.

techniques.title: Include a mechanism to pause or stop page animation
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [2.17 Ensure animation is proportionate and easy to control](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#ensure-animation-is-proportionate-and-easy-to-control).

description.1: Provide a mechanism to bypass animated effects that may be included within the page of a website or application. The buttons provided must include a stop/opt-out button as a mandatory option but may also include an option to pause and restart play as optional elements. These buttons must be visible at page load and before animation starts thereby giving the user time to action them before effects begin.
description.2: It is preferable that the buttons remain visible when scrolling the page however if the animation is restricted to a certain part of a page then the buttons can also be restricted to that region and be classed as passing the criteria. There should be one universal set of buttons for all animation rather than individual options for every effect (except media such as video).

examples.1: On the [12 Days of Web](https://12daysofweb.dev/) advent calendar for web developers, there is a toggle that can be enacted to start and stop an animated snow effect. This is particularly great as the trigger is set to opt-in animation.

procedure.1: Check if the animation has a mechanism to pause or stop animation or effects.
procedure.2: Check that the buttons load and give a grace period to the animation taking place.

techniques.title: Provide accessible mechanisms around symbols in system fonts
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [2.18 Use optimized and appropriate web typography](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#use-optimized-and-appropriate-web-typography).

description.1: Avoid rendering issues surrounding emojis and symbol typefaces based on the operating system an individual may be using or the localization of their device. This can inherently cause accessibility issues which can reduce readability as well as the aforementioned visual glitches that can potentially have an impact on system hardware.
description.2: For machine testability, flagging of symbol fonts (and potentially Emojis where operating system compatibility differences may be an issue) will increase readability if resolutions are put in place. One consideration may be to avoid using symbol fonts without an explicit justification and to only use Emojis that have endured widespread operating system compatibility.

examples.1: Because there are some issues surrounding [Emoji use and typography](https://www.tiny.cloud/blog/emojis-and-accessibility/), a guide has been put together showcasing examples of the issues that can prevent users from being able to make sense of the content.

procedure.1: Check that system fonts are replaced with accessible Emojis.
procedure.2: Check that Emojis are implemented with compatibility in mind.

techniques.title: Use modern, efficient custom typefaces within a set limit
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [2.18 Use optimized and appropriate web typography](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#use-optimized-and-appropriate-web-typography).

description.1: Optimize a typeface to ensure that when custom fonts are provided, they are implemented as sustainably as possible requiring the fewest amount of resources to download and render as possible. By placing restrictions on the number of custom typefaces and using a highly optimized format (hopefully subsetted), you will have a highly compressed file.
description.2: Multiple variables will contribute to the size of a typeface, as such, it is difficult to simply specify a hard number to aim for, but if (for example) you are not using international characters and you can subset your font, eliminating such waste could save precious resources from the fonts character table and reduce the file size considerably (reducing the system resource load upon rendering).

examples.1: [Color fonts](https://www.colorfonts.wtf/) experiment with not just custom typefaces, but with fonts that have multicolor effects built into them. This expands their file size (and is one of many factors which can impact the rendering load).

procedure.1: Check that the number of custom typefaces does not exceed five.
procedure.2: Check that fonts are preloaded within the head of the HTML document.
procedure.3: Check that no obsolete font formats are listed (such as EOT, TTF, SVG).
procedure.4: Check that fonts are only provided using WOFF2 or WOFF as a fallback.
