procedure.5: Check that if a custom font is variable enabled (refer to font a preferred), remove other references (bold, italic, etc).

techniques.title: Ensure that every PDF or other non-web document has an HTML alternative
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [2.19 Offer suitable alternatives for every format used](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#offer-suitable-alternatives-for-every-format-used).

description.1: Expand the compatibility of non-native web documents and to reduce the reliance on proprietary formats which can become an issue for users who may not have access to the software required to view the documents in question (either due to cost, the time expense of installing additional software, or the format no longer being maintained).
description.2: The alternative format provided should be in HTML as this can be marked up to be web accessible (and as an open format it can be maintained to be sustainable to meet PPP targets). The choice of which format to use should be clearly identified both using text and (if possible) using iconography, and if a default format needs to be set, having the open format is best.

examples.1: The book [Eloquent JavaScript](https://eloquentjavascript.net/) has been written primarily in HTML but also has an offline compiled PDF, ePub, and MOBI version available for individuals who would prefer to make use of these eReader-safe formats.

procedure.1: Check that all non-native web documents have an HTML alternative available.
procedure.2: Check that available formats are clearly identified with text and/or icons.
procedure.3: Check any generated HTML transcript meets the WSG.

techniques.title: Provide a suitable font stack when custom typefaces are used
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [2.19 Offer suitable alternatives for every format used](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#offer-suitable-alternatives-for-every-format-used).

description.1: Ensure cross-platform compatibility when custom fonts are utilized within a product or service. This should be done by providing at least three fallbacks across a variety of different desktop operating systems (Windows, Mac, and Linux), mobile platforms (Android and iOS), and finally offering a generic font family as a last resort to fall back upon.
description.2: Machine testing for suitable typefaces will involve a list of web-safe fonts for each platform to ensure a high probability of compatibility. Statistics about the usage of each platform can be gathered from analytics packages and used to determine which operating systems require support, from there, using a list of pre-installed fonts listed as web-safe will help you define a sustainable stack.

examples.1: [This guide](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_typefaces_included_with_macOS) provides a solid overview of web-safe typefaces across macOS, this guide provides coverage of Microsoft Windows and includes typefaces within Microsoft Office, and this guide showcases typefaces across all of Apples platforms.
examples.2: [CSS Font Stack](https://www.cssfontstack.com/) gives a list (with statistics) of Windows and Mac typefaces including their availability. It is particularly useful as it groups them based on the relative font family the typeface relates to.

procedure.1: Check all custom fonts have a generic font-family.
procedure.2: Check all custom fonts have at least three listed web-safe fallback typefaces.
procedure.3: Check that all web-safe fallback fonts cover Windows, Mac, Linux, and Mobile.

techniques.title: Provide alternative text or figure captions for images
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [2.19 Offer suitable alternatives for every format used](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#offer-suitable-alternatives-for-every-format-used).

description.1: Ensure that alternative text is available for descriptive images that are non-decorative and are important to the content of the website or application. Within HTML this can be provided either through the use of the alternative text attribute or through the use of figure captions (which are associated with an image providing added context).
description.2: Machine testability should flag any IMG element that has no alternative text unless it exists within a figure element that contains a figcaption element. There may be cases for decorative purposes where images do not require alternative text, however, these (arguably) should be identified as such and accessibility aids given the notification they can skip over them rather than being ignored.

examples.1: [MDN provides documentation](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTML/Reference/Elements/figcaption) and an example of how figcaption can be used to give contextual meaning to an image. While the example only uses an IMG element, you could embed a picture element for the same effect.
examples.2: Web Development magazine [A List Apart](https://alistapart.com/) provides alternative text on its images to ensure that those using assistive technologies can read the content without missing out on the context that they can provide.

procedure.1: Check that all IMG elements contain ALT attribute text unless within a FIGURE element with FIGCAPTION.
procedure.2: Check that SVG elements contain a TITLE and optionally a DESC element.
procedure.3: Check that CANVAS elements contain alternative textual content.
procedure.4: Check that all AREA elements (for MAP elements) contain ALT attribute text).

techniques.title: Provide a text transcription of media files in an open HTML format
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [2.19 Offer suitable alternatives for every format used](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#offer-suitable-alternatives-for-every-format-used).

description.1: Offer a transcript of the content of an audio file or video. This is especially useful within podcasts or shows that follow the linear progress of events that can be organized into chapters. How content is chosen to be written up is at the discretion of the author but to pass the criteria it must be accessible, understandable, and content complete.
description.2: As with all generated external HTML documents, for machine testability (this will include other examples such as UX51), the generated content must itself pass the WSG guidelines in being sustainable (meeting the success criteria as an HTML document that generates emissions). The document can be tested against the techniques laid down in this reference.

examples.1: The [99% Invisible podcast](https://99percentinvisible.org/episode/roman-mars-describes-chicago-as-it-is/transcript) provides text transcripts of its episodes using a paper icon to indicate availability. The speaker is clearly identified within each episode and credits are also provided alongside.

procedure.1: Check for an HTML transcript either below the media file (labeled transcript) or linked to the media.
procedure.2: Check any generated HTML transcript meets the WSG.

techniques.title: Include WebVTT closed captions, subtitles, and sign language support
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [2.19 Offer suitable alternatives for every format used](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#offer-suitable-alternatives-for-every-format-used).

description.1: Enhance existing media that has been provided to ensure maximum legibility and comprehension. In doing so, the viewer is less likely to have issues in which they rewind content to attempt to understand dialog which they had difficulty understanding (which will in turn cause bursts of CPU and GPU activity during this media manipulation).
description.2: Layering additional context upon a video may initially have an additional outlay in terms of emissions (due to the loading of additional files or rendering extra content upon the screen) but because of its social and societal benefits, it meets PPP targets and as such should be prioritized. Testers should therefore seek to identify such features and flag non-availability as an issue.

examples.1: [Meryl Evans has a great example](https://meryl.net/webvtt/) with some basic code (and links to further materials on using the WebVTT format for providing essential captioning for your videos. It is covered in [more depth on MDN](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WebVTT_API).
examples.2: Paying for a sign language interpreter for your videos can offer added value to your content. It can be easier to understand than written content, reduces accessibility issues, and increases satisfaction levels.

procedure.1: Check for iconography to identify sign language or accessible media aids.
procedure.2: Check for the availability of a WebVTT file with video files.

techniques.title: Detect form requirements and identify data collection policies
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [2.20 Provide accessible, user-friendly, minimal web forms](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#provide-accessible-user-friendly-minimal-web-forms).

description.1: Reduce the amount of inteference that occurs when information is required to be entered on a form control within a user-interface. Identify how many elements must be filled out (and those which are not mandatory being eliminated), clearly label how such components need to be filled out (and how many steps there are), plus have links to data collection policies.
description.2: Such actions can lead to less unnecessary data transmission which is not only beneficial in terms of privacy and security (the people and societal component of PPP) but also having fewer form elements or steps to render will have an emissions reduction due to the lower amount of individual elements to render to the screen (and the user will spend less time on-screen filling the forms in).

examples.1: Domain Registrar [iWantMyName](https://new.help.iwantmyname.com/hc/en-gb) takes form filling to the most minimal extent possible on their contact page, only providing three essential fields to deal with requests, each of which is clearly labeled.
examples.2: The [registration page for BBC iPlayer](https://account.bbc.com/register) is a multi-step process that is well designed and labeled to avoid overwhelming new users and it only requests the minimum amount of data necessary to set up an account.
examples.3: This [medical diagnosis application](https://symptomate.com/) decides what information is required to be filled in next upon the previous submission, thereby only relevant questions are being asked (leading to less redundancy in form filling).

procedure.1: Check how many steps there are in an input process and if this can be reduced.
procedure.2: Check that all form components are clearly labeled and disclose their purpose.
procedure.3: Check that only necessary form elements are displayed onscreen.
procedure.4: Check that a publicly displayed data collection policy link is visible (this may be a section of a privacy policy).

techniques.title: Allow for data entry with automatic assistance settings
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [2.20 Provide accessible, user-friendly, minimal web forms](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#provide-accessible-user-friendly-minimal-web-forms).

description.1: Provide a mechanism within forms during necessary data entry to allow automated tooling to provide necessary assistance. Such data entry will cause users to spend less time onscreen and as such will generate fewer emissions in addition to less frustration from failed attempts that would otherwise lead to potential escalation of such emissions being triggered (while also conserving bandwidth).
description.2: For machine testability, the autocomplete attribute should be disabled in all form inputs outside of those likely to be utilized/assisted by a password manager (this is especially true where the suggestions do not come from a user device but a third-party and additional bandwidth or rendering processes are likely to be endured). A list of such inputs can be identified from a common password manager and marked against each form for correctness.

examples.1: [Login forms such as Grammerly](https://www.grammarly.com/signin) can be detected by password manager software and therefore have a benefit for autocompletion (as users cannot be expected to remember personal details across all websites).
examples.2: [Filling in an application form](https://www.jotform.com/form-templates/job-application) should allow autocomplete for elements of a profile that may be contained within a password manager (such as name, email, and phone), but should be disabled in all other formats to prevent the text element from attempting to anticipate the user's responses.
examples.3: The HTML Hell advent calendar [has a great article on providing autocomplete](https://www.htmhell.dev/tips/autocompleting-password-fields/) for the sake of third-party tooling access such as password managers. It includes a range of examples and links to additionally useful articles that might guide decision-making.

procedure.1: Check that autocomplete is enabled in all username and password fields.
procedure.2: Check that autocomplete is enabled in all identity (E.G. address, email) fields.
procedure.3: Check that autocomplete is disabled in all other input fields.

techniques.title: Provide compatibility for non-visual browsing methods
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [2.21 Consider the experience in non-visual browsers and interfaces](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#consider-the-experience-in-non-visual-browsers-and-interfaces).

description.1: Provide a mechanism for those not using a screen as a primary method of browsing to have an equal browsing experience. This is primarily due to screens being a high emitter of emissions in terms of energy usage, but also with the increase in speech-powered devices, the need for support mechanisms to be in place has increased in recent years.
description.2: Detection of such support can be clearly identified with good semantics and high-quality content as a foundation, however for machine testability, thresholds such as having a speech stylesheet in place (that can help with issues around pronunciation and tone) and testing projects within text browsers for fundamental mechanical issues are critical to establish a pass.

examples.1: The [Lynx text browser](https://lynx.invisible-island.net/) is one of the oldest maintained browsers on the Internet and it can be particularly useful in identifying issues around keyboard navigation and non-visual browsing when features are unavailable.
examples.2: This [article from Smashing Magazine](https://www.smashingmagazine.com/2020/12/making-websites-accessible/) describes in detail how websites and applications can make their work easier for non-visual devices such as speech environments (like cars and smart speakers) to access.

procedure.1: Check for a speech stylesheet for indicators to clarify pronunciation issues.
procedure.2: Check that your website or application functions correctly in a text-only environment.

techniques.title: Provide error detection when user input is required
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [2.22 Provide useful notifications](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#provide-useful-notifications).

description.1: Provide a mechanism to notify the user if an issue has occurred during the form-filling process that may be remedied either before or after the submission process has occurred to resolve the issue before it reaches its intended location. Providing error detection and assistance can reduce screen time searching for answers.
description.2: Machine testability for error detection would require the submission of dummy data (incorrectly) into a form of required elements to test the durability of the process to see if instructional recommendations are given. Such prompts that either correct or guide the user can be deemed to pass the success criteria. If no guidance is offered or if forms are incorrectly labeled, leading to errors, this would qualify as a failure.

examples.1: This [example of client-side form validation](https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/working-examples/script-form-validation-2/index.php) based on [WCAG Technique SCR32](https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/Techniques/client-side-script/SCR32.html) showcases a classic example of error handling and how providing a response to the user input when failure occurs is important.
examples.2: [UX Writing Hub](https://uxwritinghub.com/error-message-examples/) provides some great examples of how errors in content, forms, and other parts of a page or application can be successfully written to ensure users do not feel undermined and can continue navigate successfully.

procedure.1: Check that HTML form components are correctly labeled (for example, required elements, and content types).
procedure.2: Check that JavaScript error handling is provided for the client-side (pre-submission).
procedure.3: Check that server-side error handling is provided for post-submission (no JavaScript) issues.
procedure.4: Check that all prompts occur in a suitable location, relative to the error occurring.

techniques.title: Add a print-friendly media query or stylesheet
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [2.23 Reduce the impact of downloadable and physical documents](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#reduce-the-impact-of-downloadable-and-physical-documents).

description.1: Reduce the amount of excessive paper and ink resource mineral waste produced from the physical printing of documents by users of your products and services. By creating a customized print stylesheet you can optimize the use of these resources and improve readability of the layout if the document is exported into a static format such as PDF.
description.2: This technique is most useful when it covers a lot of issues that physical formats can suffer over their digital counterparts (such as no interactivity), the necessity of color usage or content, breaks in flow and pages, etc. Machine testability can examine the stylesheet for such feature handling as compliance with success criteria (link expansion, paper size support, CSS resets, etc).

examples.1: The [Printed CSS Framework](https://printedcss.com/) contains a multitude of features intended to reduce the impact of printed media, with additional support for handling a range of special developer set cases that can be defined in HTML.

procedure.1: Check that the website or application has a print-friendly media query (@print) or stylesheet.
procedure.2: Check that the print CSS makes attribute content and URLs visible
procedure.3: Check that the print CSS considers content color accuracy and monochrome options
procedure.4: Check that the print CSS considers paper orientation, color, and size
procedure.5: Check that the print CSS hides unnecessary structural material

techniques.title: Optimizing all document assets across a variety of different formats
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [2.23 Reduce the impact of downloadable and physical documents](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#reduce-the-impact-of-downloadable-and-physical-documents).

description.1: Ensure that non-web documents are not only served in a range of compatible (suitable) formats for the device requesting them but also to make sure that the documents being served have been compressed using a suitable algorithm to provide the asset at the lowest bandwidth requirements possible to the user, thereby improving multiple PPP variables and increasing performance.
description.2: Compression tests can be run against every document format to identify if improvements can be made without losing too much quality that visibility becomes degraded and therefore a recognition issue (in embedded images and media within). The primary format given to users should be the one with the widest compatibility for viewing within the browser plugin-free (usually PDF).

examples.1: A legal document that an individual will need to read through before potentially taking part in an offline process (that is partially handled online) may require such a process. Avoiding the necessity to download and install additional software wherever possible will reduce emissions.

procedure.1: Check that the primary document format is the most browser-compatible.
procedure.2: Check that more than one format is given if a non-web format is offered for compatibility.
procedure.3: Check for compression potential against every available document asset.
procedure.4: Provide optimized solutions if document problems have been detected.

techniques.title: Provide pre-generated copies of repeat-use physical assets
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [2.23 Reduce the impact of downloadable and physical documents](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#reduce-the-impact-of-downloadable-and-physical-documents).

description.1: Ensure that any document that is likely to be requested by users on multiple occasions is already compiled and generated at the source and available for download rather than generating a brand new asset upon each user request. This will reduce the emissions of having to repeat the same task over and over for unchanging content or materials that have little interaction potential.
description.2: For machine testability, identifying that large web assets are available from a static address such as a CDN is one method of meeting the success criteria, another would be to scan through scripts for generative code that creates web assets to determine if such content could be better served through recompilation. If this is the case, warnings and remedial action should be issued.

examples.1: [GoalKicker](https://goalkicker.com/) provides a range of free Notes on various programming languages, each of which is precompiled to PDF format and therefore not generated on the server-side. This optimizes their delivery to the user.

procedure.1: Check that existing web assets are pre-generated for repeat-use.
procedure.2: Check code for asset compilation to identify if pre-generation would be better.

techniques.title: Provide document details including a URL within a page
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [2.23 Reduce the impact of downloadable and physical documents](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#reduce-the-impact-of-downloadable-and-physical-documents).

description.1: Provide a mechanism for individuals to access downloadable or embeddable documents without the material having been embedded within the document. Embedded content has an attributable carbon cost due to the rendering of the host applications processes as well as the content and there is a chance users clicked a link in error.
description.2: Providing structural information about resources including direct links to files in preference to auto-loading content keeps the user in control, avoiding the loading and rendering of necessary resources. Machine testability of such components can test for embedded elements to avoid clearly marked-up document descriptions and direct URL links that are user-enacted.

examples.1: Smashing Magazine provides a copy of their [front-end performance checklist](https://www.smashingmagazine.com/2021/01/front-end-performance-2021-free-pdf-checklist/) in a multitude of formats, and this is described with direct links at the top of their open HTML version of the same document.

procedure.1: Check that document pages do not embed large files (internally or with third-parties).
procedure.2: Check that document links are clearly described with information about name, format, language, size, and potentially a summary.
procedure.3: Check for choice options with format and language variables in documents.

techniques.title: Identify an affected party-focused testing and prototyping policy
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [2.24 Get users and contributors invested in the project](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#get-users-and-contributors-invested-in-the-project).

description.1: Identify the way new features, product ideas, and user-interface components will be tested among various affected party groups such as those with with accessibility issues. The main location for such an outline will be through an affected party-focused testing and prototyping policy and as such once implemented publicly, a link to the policy should be available.
description.2: Machine detection could use heuristics to identify key policies within the text, however at a basic level, being able to identify the policy exists, potentially within the footer of a website or application along with other policies and legal documents, and then further analysis of individual headline elements of key sections of the document, should be enough to justify a passing criteria.

examples.1: The [UK Government](https://www.gov.uk/service-manual/user-research/using-moderated-usability-testing) has a publicly visible Usability Testing (User Research) guide within their service manual which outlines the processes they aim to follow when conducting such activities for their service.
examples.2: The [University of St Andrews](https://www.st-andrews.ac.uk/digital-standards/policies/usability-testing/) has a publicly facing Usability Testing Policy that covers and applies to all staff that undertake usability testing at the campus at that university. It is well broken down and explanatory.

procedure.1: Check if a Testing policy is both published and publicly visible.
procedure.2: Check for key policy factors are presented within the text (optional).

techniques.title: Produce a list of checkpoints to ensure quality control
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [2.25 Audit and test for bugs or issues requiring resolution](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#audit-and-test-for-bugs-or-issues-requiring-resolution).

description.1: Produce a comprehensive maintainable list of quality assurance lists across a range of different categories not limited to bugs, security, web performance, accessibility, sustainability, etc. By having this list in place, everyone involved in the creation process can closely monitor the application or website against each checkpoint to identify resolutions either before, during, or after a product or service is launched.
description.2: This list should be created during ideation if possible but can also be machine-generated from a pre-determined set of lists relating to these topics based upon evidence and research. The content of this material can potentially be further tested through automation however at a bare minimum, this list must be utilized in-house to enact sustainable change. For machine testability, if this list is not publicly visible, internal access will be required to determine creation.

examples.1: [Lighthouse](https://developer.chrome.com/docs/lighthouse/overview?hl=en) is an open source project which enables both the auditing and production of reports of websites and applications for several common issues across a range of categories from within a web browser.

procedure.1: Check to see if deliverables require internal access (if so, permission is given).
procedure.2: Check that the testing regime is available (internally or externally).
procedure.3: Identify all bug and security tests to perform during the testing process.
procedure.4: Identify all web performance tests to perform during the testing process.
procedure.5: Identify all web accessibility tests to perform during the testing process.
procedure.6: Identify all web sustainability tests to perform during the testing process.
procedure.7: Report and resolve the findings within your auditing process.

techniques.title: Provide active monitoring for issues on a frequent schedule
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [2.25 Audit and test for bugs or issues requiring resolution](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#audit-and-test-for-bugs-or-issues-requiring-resolution).

description.1: Ensure that problems relating to the sustainability of a website can be picked up with more frequency and regularity. Within the scope of website and application testing, it is important to be actively monitoring for common failure points that build over time and upon being notified of said issues provide resolutions within a reasonable timeframe.
description.2: Machine testability for this implementation will be based on the mechanism used for testing. For instance, if a product or service provider chooses to simply run routine tests on a scheduled basis this may be considered a pass as long as the time between scans is frequent enough that it can be considered active in opposition to occasional (weekly would be the widest margin).

examples.1: [Speedcurve](https://www.speedcurve.com/) is a commercial product that actively monitors websites for performance issues (broken down by category in rendering) and can provide advisory guidance on meeting targets for performance budgets.
examples.2: [Google Search Console](https://search.google.com/search-console/about) is a free product that monitors websites for issues that may affect their ability to be indexed within the Google search engine, which notably can impact their overall global page visibility.

procedure.1: Check that testing occurs hourly/daily/weekly to be considered active.
procedure.2: Check that all publicly visible pages are included within the monitoring.
procedure.3: Check that the facility providing the monitoring meets the WSG.
procedure.4: Check that a report of ongoing listed issues is publicly available until fully resolved.
procedure.5: Provide resolutions for detected issues within a timely manner.

techniques.title: Scan for introduced issues upon the completion of a new release
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [2.25 Audit and test for bugs or issues requiring resolution](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#audit-and-test-for-bugs-or-issues-requiring-resolution).

description.1: Provide a mechanism for eliminating any potential new flaws that may have been introduced into a website or application upon the release of a new version that will have additional updates or features that could break functionality if not implemented correctly. As such, enforcing a sustainability scan across a series of variables is critical.
description.2: For machine testability, the necessity of automation of running a scan could be triggered on the publication of each new release, or for more nuanced control (where active monitoring already exists and non-breaking features are being introduced), a scan could be triggered only where only a major release is issued when breaking changes are more likely to occur.

examples.1: [Accessibility scanners](https://www.w3.org/WAI/test-evaluate/tools/list/) can use the machine-testable elements of WCAG to help identify issues that can be resolved. While they are not a silver bullet and cannot replace manual audits they can identify some issues.

procedure.1: Check that all publicly visible pages are included within the monitoring.
procedure.2: Check for a wide variety of issues within the scope of the WSG.
procedure.3: Check that a report of ongoing listed issues is publicly available until fully resolved.
procedure.4: Provide resolutions for detected issues within a timely manner.

techniques.title: Establish performance testing routines with each new release
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [2.26 Measure and test for performance](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#measure-and-test-for-performance).

description.1: Encourage a routine to improve web performance within websites and applications due to the established link between web performance optimization and digital sustainability. Running regular benchmarks and working from checklists (either prefabricated or built from scratch) will encourage a schedule to identify potential bottlenecks.
description.2: The content of these testing routines can potentially be further tested through automation however at a bare minimum, this list must be utilized in-house to enact sustainable change. For machine testability, if this list is not publicly visible, internal access will be required to determine whether creation has taken place.

examples.1: Smashing Magazine has a comprehensive [front-end performance checklist](https://www.smashingmagazine.com/2021/01/front-end-performance-2021-free-pdf-checklist/) that could be utilized as part of a routine in release schedule checking for web performance issues that may exist or have been introduced.
examples.2: [Addy Osmani back in 2018](https://dev.to/ben/addy-osmanis-18-point-web-performance-checklist-2e1) created an 18-point web performance checklist that if you are looking for something more simplistic and rapid to compare builds against could potentially be very useful as a starting point.

procedure.1: Check to see if deliverables require internal access (if so, permission is given).
procedure.2: Check that the testing regime is available (internally or externally).
procedure.3: Identify all web performance tests to perform during the testing process.
procedure.4: Report and resolve the findings within your auditing process.

techniques.title: Provide compliance checks with each release for relevant legislation
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [2.26 Measure and test for performance](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#measure-and-test-for-performance).

description.1: Provide a mechanism during the development process where businesses and individuals creating web projects can verify that new work meets compliance targets for individual regulations. This technique is most useful when performed with each major milestone as there is a potential for feature (and compliance) breaking material to occur.
description.2: Within the scope of sustainability, this is increasingly important as there are explicit laws surrounding the subject in addition to expanded PPP remits such as accessibility, privacy, etc. In terms of machine testability the mechanics of an implementation may be more difficult than utilizing an automated checker, but wizard software can work through questions to help identify key issues.

examples.1: Internationally reaching environmental legislation such as [CSRD](https://finance.ec.europa.eu/capital-markets-union-and-financial-markets/company-reporting-and-auditing/company-reporting/corporate-sustainability-reporting_en) and the [Green Claims Directive](https://www.europarl.europa.eu/news/en/press-room/20240112IPR16772/meps-adopt-new-law-banning-greenwashing-and-misleading-product-information) provide stricter enforcement around product descriptions and the need to reduce emissions and accurately report such efforts.
examples.2: Accessibility legislation ([of which there are many worldwide](https://www.w3.org/WAI/policies/)) provides strict enforcement around ensuring inclusivity not just offline but also in the digital sphere as well, leaving non-compliance open to lawsuit risks.
examples.3: Internationally reaching privacy legislation such as [GDPR](https://gdpr-info.eu/) can also impact digital services on a sustainability level (through the people and societal aspect of PPP), and [various](https://gdpr.eu/checklist/) [checklists](https://gdprchecklist.io/) can assist.

procedure.1: Check to see if deliverables require internal access (if so, permission is given).
procedure.2: Check that the testing regime is available (internally or externally).
procedure.3: Identify all relevant compliance checks to perform during testing process.
procedure.4: Report and resolve the findings within your auditing process.

techniques.title: Provide a publicly visible compatibility policy or statement
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [2.29 Regularly test and maintain compatibility](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#regularly-test-and-maintain-compatibility).

description.1: Ensure that users are made aware of (or able to find out) the limitations of a product or service before issuing a support request that will involve creating new emission sources. This compatibility policy can be listed amongst other policies on a website, however, it must contain detailed information about any factor that may have reduced capability.
description.2: For machine testability, attempt to first establish that the policy exists and then try using heuristics (or identification of the headlines) to locate sections on what is both actively supported (those conditions tested upon), and those that are confirmed as unsupported (those conditions known to be broken but will not be fixed with reasons given). Ensure that a support method is also provided.

examples.1: British cellphone provider GiffGaff provides a [web browser support policy](https://www.giffgaff.design/guidelines/browser-support-policy/) that identifies which browsers they support and do not actively support plus they also offer the [justification behind their decisions](https://www.giffgaff.io/tech/creating-a-browser-support-policy).

procedure.1: Check for a compatibility policy or statement's existence.
procedure.2: Check for sections on included and excluded coverage.
procedure.3: Check that a support method is offered for issues outside of scope.

techniques.title: Provide clarification when updates are significant over minor releases
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [2.29 Regularly test and maintain compatibility](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#regularly-test-and-maintain-compatibility).

description.1: Provide a mechanism for introducing users to new features and capabilities within websites and applications upon a major release being triggered. This would include compatibility changes, any alterations that affect workflow, and bugs that have been resolved. It applies equally to both applications on upgrade paths and website redesigns.
description.2: The importance of re-orientating users around breaking changes is crucial as modifications made could lead to errors in usage, increases in technical support, problematic friction in usability or accessibility, or introduction of issues that may lead to multiple impacting PPP factors that could be resolved through training, answered questions, and well-signposted information architecture.

examples.1: Using [Semantic Versioning](https://semver.org/), providers through their release notes (which if publicly available could be machine tested against), could easily identify a major (breakable significant), against a minor (non-breaking) release.

procedure.1: Check for a publicly available change.log or release notes.
procedure.2: Check that the frequency of updates has not been less than 12 months.
procedure.3: Check that major releases provide details of breaking features.

techniques.title: Establish compatibility testing routines with each new release
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [2.29 Regularly test and maintain compatibility](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#regularly-test-and-maintain-compatibility).

description.1: Ensure that compatibility issues resulting from user constraints (such as operating system or browser age/connection speed, availability, or cost) are factored into the testing process at each new release. Creators must have processes in place whether through checklists that are pre-created or crafted from scratch to ensure that a regime is in place.
description.2: In terms of machine testability, some tools can provide virtualized emulations of certain operating systems and thereby load products and services to undertake tests (or screenshots) to examine compatibility. Data also exists regarding mobile data charges and connection speeds which can be used to emulate or identify the compatibility costs associated with projects.

examples.1: [Browser Stack](https://www.browserstack.com/) and [LambadaTest](https://www.lambdatest.com/) provide virtual testing (which can be automated) amongst a variety of common web browsers allowing testers to identify flaws in their website or application's compatibility.
examples.2: [Can I Use](https://caniuse.com/) provides a comprehensive guide to browser implementations of web standards, including known bugs, and thereby can help guide implementors with decision making when deciding how to progressively enhance their product or service.

procedure.1: Check to see if deliverables require internal access (if so, permission is given).
procedure.2: Check that the testing regime is available (internally or externally).
procedure.3: Identify all compatibility tests to perform during the testing process.
procedure.4: Check if additional legal compliance requirements are being met.
procedure.5: Report and resolve the findings within your auditing process.

techniques.title: Provide a PWA if more suitable than its native counterpart
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [2.29 Regularly test and maintain compatibility](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#regularly-test-and-maintain-compatibility).

description.1: Identify a web application that exists and then determine if turning the web application into a progressive web application would be more beneficial than providing a native offering. This would need to take into account current web capabilities (such as ServiceWorkers), methods of delivery (such as WASM), and the human aspect (audience requirements).
description.2: Machine testability can firstly examine the existing state of an application to determine how sustainable it is and what technology stack was used to develop it (and how sustainable it already performs for all), from there, data points can be used to identify an approximate cost of implementation for both a native or highly optimized web application endpoint and options can be provided.

examples.1: Native applications may be a good choice if applications require specific access to hardware as web APIs can still be quite restrictive. In addition, there is a case for going native to provide a more OS-centric look and feel.
examples.2: web applications are often quicker and easier to deploy and can provide updates without delays in the pipeline (as they do not have to go through store controls), they can also benefit from lower creation costs.

procedure.1: Check if the existing application already utilizes a ServiceWorker.
procedure.2: If so, check the PWA JavaScript and JSON are well formed, and the icon exists.
procedure.3: If not calculate the sustainability impact of becoming a PWA.
procedure.4: Check that no native application already exists ([meta tag smart banner](https://developer.apple.com/documentation/webkit/promoting-apps-with-smart-app-banners)).
procedure.5: If so use that, otherwise calculate the sustainability impact of building an application.
procedure.6: If cost-efficient sustainability-wise, implement a PWA or/and a native application.

techniques.title: Profile existing projects to identify common variables of value
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [3.1 Set goals based on performance and energy impact](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#set-goals-based-on-performance-and-energy-impact).

description.1: Identify any technical indicators which may be of use within a sustainability budget or those that can be immediately identified as exceeding a recommended level for an average page size thereby indicating that the document should be split or broken down into either two or more pieces to reduce the impact of the experience upon the user.
description.2: Factors that may be taken into account could include an extremely long document that would require excessive scrolling (based on either the visual spacing or the number of DOM elements involved), the number of DOM elements could also be a factor as too many could produce unwarranted rendering loads, also excessive HTTP requests can produce a lot of overhead.

examples.1: Websites that need to display a large number of icons may choose to bundle the [vector images into a sprite](https://levelup.gitconnected.com/build-an-icon-system-with-svg-sprites-a-complete-guide-1e195820ac6a) which avoids the HTTP requests overhead and allows requesting (and repeat usage) through references.

procedure.1: Check the visual spacing of elements is not too cramped.
procedure.2: Check the scroll length of the document does not exceed a stated length.
procedure.3: Check the number of DOM nodes in the tree does not exceed a stated number.
procedure.4: Check the number of HTTP requests does not exceed a stated number.
procedure.5: Check if optimizing will be beneficial, if so, implement a solution.

techniques.title: Calculate the energy intensity of technologies for existing projects
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [3.1 Set goals based on performance and energy impact](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#set-goals-based-on-performance-and-energy-impact).

description.1: Distinguish different technologies and the role they play, identifying which are the most resource-intensive and providing either a mechanism to reduce the intensity of heavy payloads or to load-balance the most demanding aspects of these features. It is important to consider that in terms of rendering, data transfer is not the only consideration.
description.2: In terms of machine testability, calculating the percentage of HTML, CSS, JavaScript, images, media, etc, is not enough. It is critical to weigh and calculate the energy requirements of each aspect of those languages on an atomic level to identify potential rendering issues from the browser as these will impact upon hardware (CPU, GPU, RAM, and other variables) having PPP implications.

examples.1: Primary [research exists](https://websitesustainability.com/#content) to calculate the energy intensity of front-end specifications and this could guide your ability to identify the energy intensity of components beyond the amount of data transferred.
examples.2: [Co2.js](https://www.thegreenwebfoundation.org/co2-js/) is a JavaScript library that can help developers estimate the relative carbon emissions of their applications, websites, and software using several variables (though it will not account for everything).

procedure.1: Check the energy intensity of the HTML elements and attributes used.
procedure.2: Check the energy intensity of CSS At-Rules, Selectors, Pseudo's, Properties, and Values.
procedure.3: Check the energy intensity of JavaScript, DOM, CSSOM, and API usage.
procedure.4: Check the energy intensity of image and media usage.

techniques.title: Minify your front-end code if it is public facing
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [3.2 Remove unnecessary or redundant information](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#remove-unnecessary-or-redundant-information).

description.1: Provide a mechanism in which your production-ready source code can have unnecessary data such as code comments, whitespace data, and machine-detectable redundancy removed to deliver the smallest file payload possible to the user. This will improve both the speed of your site and lower screen usage (wait) time.
description.2: In terms of machine testability, the functions of a minification tool can be replicated for the languages HTML, CSS, and JavaScript using scripts and these can identify improvements to be made. Function names can be uglified (shortened to the smallest value) to reduce the size of the payload further and reporting tools can make recommendations based upon feedback.

examples.1: Projects that are both public-facing but also allow for others to contribute to development should allow for [un-minification](https://unminify.com/). Developer tooling often contains features or extensions to restore code to a readable state.
examples.2: [Mithril](https://mithril.js.org/) is an example of a JavaScript framework that uses minification to great effect. It is small to start with but by offering both developer and minified versions on its GitHub repository you get the best of both worlds.

procedure.1: Check if your HTML, CSS, and JavaScript can be minified.
procedure.2: Check if JavaScript can gain size reductions through uglify processes.
procedure.3: Check if the code is on a non-production public-facing website.
procedure.4: Check if obfuscation exists, if not minify the source code.

techniques.title: Implement code-splitting where appropriate to reduce payloads
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [3.3 Modularize bandwidth-heavy components](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#modularize-bandwidth-heavy-components).

description.1: Provide a mechanism where modularization can occur to reduce the overall payload of applications, libraries, and frameworks for the web. By using code-splitting and modules where isolating code can take place (machine-testability can detect this), large components can be successfully broken down into pieces that will be delivered as required.
description.2: This technique is most useful when dealing with significant-sized or complex pieces of production code that may not be required to be delivered in a single volume. If functionality will be used on-demand (for example), the payload to activate and run the functionality could be fetched and run when it is needed instead of the entire applications library being gathered upon page load.

examples.1: MDN [provides a detailed guide](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Guide/Modules) to JavaScript modules that are contained within many frameworks today to split them into separate component-based libraries to be called only when they are required by the user.
examples.2: Separating CSS into stylesheets based on arguments such as [media or preference queries](https://polypane.app/blog/the-complete-guide-to-css-media-queries/) (or in rarer instances using imports), allows for large stylistic libraries to be broken down and requested only if its necessary.
examples.3: [Alpine](https://alpinejs.dev/) is a JavaScript framework that uses modules effectively to import the features it requires, and as such, remains fast and lightweight compared to competing frameworks that load everything in one go.

procedure.1: Check the size of packages to determine the benefit of code-splitting.
procedure.2: Check if CSS would benefit from being split into separate stylesheets based on queries.
procedure.3: Check if JavaScript can be modularized and imported when required.
procedure.4: Check if obfuscation exists, if not code-split the source code.

techniques.title: Eliminate redundant code through coverage or tree shaking
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [3.4 Remove unnecessary code](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#remove-unnecessary-code).

description.1: Eliminate redundancy within an application or website that may have been either introduced previously or through error. By using browser development tooling such as DevTools coverage or techniques like tree shaking any code which is no longer associated with functionality can be identified as potentially fit for removal (always verify this is accurate).
description.2: For machine testability, redundant (orphaned/unused) code can be identified by its lack of association with existing components within the web page or application. Consideration will also need to be given to components that may be generated mid or post-render in addition to styles that only trigger when a certain state occurs (such as through hover or the target pseudo selector).

examples.1: [This article by Jeremy Wagner](https://web.dev/articles/reduce-javascript-payloads-with-tree-shaking?hl=en) showcases the importance of tree shaking within projects, including the history behind it and how it functions, in addition, it provides a few useful code examples.
examples.2: You can identify unused code within a project using Google Developer Tools in the [Coverage Panel](https://developer.chrome.com/docs/devtools/coverage?hl=en-us). While there are a few gotchas (such as identifying inactive pseudo selectors), it is a useful way to weed CSS.

procedure.1: Check CSS to determine if redundancy exists within your code.
procedure.2: Check packages to determine if redundancy exists within JavaScript.
procedure.3: Check if redundant code may be reintroduced, if not, remove it.

techniques.title: Write code for performance removing duplication
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [3.5 Avoid redundancy and duplication in code](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#avoid-redundancy-and-duplication-in-code).

description.1: Provide a mechanism within projects to eliminate redundancy within your coding methodology. There will be occasions where the same solution is required for multiple events and in preference to repeating the code to achieve the same effect, referencing the code to perform on each occasion is more optimal as it reduces duplication and repetition.
description.2: In terms of machine testability, usage of DRY, repeated CSS property and value pairs (or in JavaScript, code that repeats the same action) can be identified and flagged as appropriate in cases where the implementation is correct or incorrect based upon the pattern. Where patterns add unnecessary bloat to a page (such as CSS methodologies), detection can be identified and flagged in such instances.

examples.1: [DRY](https://csswizardry.com/2013/07/writing-dryer-vanilla-css/ is a methodology that is commonly used by creating reusable components and patterns, using easier-to-name schemes and most importantly, avoiding already established code.

procedure.1: Check for energy inefficient naming methodologies or patterns in CSS.
procedure.2: Check for the absence of repeating code (DRY) within CSS.
procedure.3: Check for duplicate functionality or names within your JavaScript.

techniques.title: Determine and decision make upon third-party impacts
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [3.6 Give third parties the same priority as first parties during assessment](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#give-third-parties-the-same-priority-as-first-parties-during-assessment).

description.1: First identify any third-party components within a website or application, then analyze that feature as if it were a first-party product or service (against the WSG) for sustainability. If the product or service is determined to be highly impactful in a negative way, the third-party should be replaced or removed; otherwise, it can be optimized, or stay as-is.
description.2: As third-party components are hosted externally, machine testing these elements should involve isolating these components and testing them as separate from the product or service. This can be factored into any decision-making regarding inclusion as highly performant and sustainable third-party materials will ultimately be low impact (and the opposite is true for others).

examples.1: [OpenStreetMap](https://wiki.openstreetmap.org/wiki/Using_OpenStreetMap) allows for [embedding of their map data](https://medium.com/@nargessmi87/how-to-embede-open-street-map-in-a-webpage-like-google-maps-8968fdad7fe4) in websites and applications which can be useful for providing directions to physical locations, but it could also drain data and rendering resources.
examples.2: A carousel with multiple resources (potentially being sourced from a third-party photo library) could be pretty to look at, but the combination of both animation and rendering may affect your user's battery.

procedure.1: Check if any third-party components exist within the page or application.
procedure.2: Check that component against the WSG for its sustainability compliance.
procedure.3: Check if high-impact third-party components offer self-hosted alternatives.
procedure.4: Check that self-hosted alternatives are used if provided.

techniques.title: Provide an import on interaction delay for third-party resources
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [3.6 Give third parties the same priority as first parties during assessment](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#give-third-parties-the-same-priority-as-first-parties-during-assessment).

description.1: Provide a mechanism to delay third-party content from loading to the screen until the user has requested it. Because third-party content is sourced from outside the origin domain, the sustainability impacts of the third-party code are outside of the control of a project, and thus click-to-load delay screens using the import-on-interaction pattern is critical.
description.2: The pattern used to either switch in the third-party content or load it on-demand can be machine-identified and if common third-party library resources are identified as loading (or leaking) upon a visit, this can and should be flagged up as a failure of the success criteria in functioning upon the user request (as such external requests should be within the user control).

examples.1: [BBC News](https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-68590845) uses a cloaking mechanism to prevent third-party content of social media sites from loading unless requested by the user to reduce the impact on their devices (if this fails to work, a source link is offered).

procedure.1: Check if any third-party components exist within the page or application.
procedure.2: Check that it exists behind a click-to-load delay screen (that users must request).

techniques.title: Identify lightweight alternatives to unsustainable third-party resources
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [3.6 Give third parties the same priority as first parties during assessment](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#give-third-parties-the-same-priority-as-first-parties-during-assessment).

description.1: Reduce the overhead of libraries and frameworks which may be used by the product or service but could be offered through lighter or less production-heavy alternatives. This will have significant sustainability benefits as replacing a heavyweight framework where only a small proportion of features are used with one that is potentially 1/5th of the size could not only improve performance but reduce the rendering load.
description.2: This will require testability tooling to have both a library of existing frameworks and libraries - including smaller single-purpose ones (with the functionality they contain) and the ability to identify within code the feature set that is being utilized by a product or service. Through isolating in-use capabilities, better recommendations can be made which could reduce the project payload.

examples.1: [You Might Not Need jQuery](https://youmightnotneedjquery.com/) provides information about potential replacements for the longstanding JavaScript framework that could be more performant and lightweight while offering the same functionality.
examples.2: [You (Might) Don't Need jQuery](https://github.com/camsong/You-Dont-Need-jQuery) showcases a series of examples of how pre-existing jQuery functionality can now be replaced with native functionality and as such, the framework could be eliminated.
examples.3: [MicroJS](http://microjs.com/#) is a list of tiny JavaScript frameworks that serve a single purpose and if you utilize a single large framework for this very reason, could be swapped out to reduce the environmental impact of your work.

procedure.1: Check if CSS libraries could be replaced with smaller alternatives or custom code.
procedure.2: Check if JavaScript frameworks could be replaced with smaller alternatives or native code.
procedure.3: If replacements can be made, then replacements should be introduced.

techniques.title: Ensure that content is delivered through the most sustainable pathway
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [3.6 Give third parties the same priority as first parties during assessment](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#give-third-parties-the-same-priority-as-first-parties-during-assessment).

description.1: Identify the location of website content and determine the most suitable pathway for it to be consumed sustainably. With the rise in content being hosted on third-party blogging platforms, there is a risk of significant content loss if the platform disappears and therefore a need for self-hosting exists (especially to maintain control of sustainability impacts).
description.2: For machine testability, identifying the source of the content is a key priority, then determining the impact of any third-party (the risk of content loss along with any sustainability impacts through WSG testing). Finally, this should be weighed up against the impact of self-hosting (and any potential negative consequences such as content moderation requirements that may occur).

examples.1: [Medium](https://medium.com/) is a popular content hosting platform yet while it does offer a reasonably readable interface, it may not be as sustainable as providing the content within your own website or application in a dedicated blog.
examples.2: Social media posts are contained within your account on that network (in some social networks are only visible to members or even users of a mobile application) and will have the sustainability issues of that provider.

procedure.1: Check if the level of content being published is regular.
procedure.2: Check if features such as comments are a requirement (if so, can moderation be offered).
procedure.3: Check if the website already has an audience to give content visibility.
procedure.4: If so, check that the content is self-hosted on the first-party domain.

techniques.title: Create custom clickable icons and widgets for third-party services
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [3.6 Give third parties the same priority as first parties during assessment](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#give-third-parties-the-same-priority-as-first-parties-during-assessment).

description.1: Provide a mechanism for interacting with third-party products and services through your own project without having to rely on a third-party solution that will inevitably have tied sustainability impacts that are bound to a third-party service. Creating these custom repeatable use objects can have either a single function use, or can serve multiple functions.
description.2: Identification of third-party solutions can be found through heuristics of source code and recommendations can be made to produce custom first-party solutions for sustainably impactful services. Additionally, custom solutions can often be identified based on either the goal they aim to achieve or the label they are given within HTML ID or class names that can be identified.

examples.1: There are [many examples](https://freefrontend.com/css-social-media-icons/) of custom social media icons [embedding](https://codepen.io/sanketbodke/pen/LYymbRq) out there, and there are also plenty of [free libraries](https://simpleicons.org/) out there you can choose between to avoid relying on the default offerings by providers.

procedure.1: Check that the product or service has accounts with different service providers.
procedure.2: Check that a custom solution is either in link form, icon form, or looks similar to the provider's native implementation.

techniques.title: Provide the ability to identify and choose third-party components to load
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [3.6 Give third parties the same priority as first parties during assessment](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#give-third-parties-the-same-priority-as-first-parties-during-assessment).

description.1: Provide users with the optimum level of control over sustainability impacts by not just allowing them to identify and load third-party controls upon click but to also control third-party services, libraries, and tooling used by the product or service (even at load) via a preference panel where individual third-parties (which may be impactful) can be refused access.
description.2: This mechanism if using a commonly accepted scheme could be detected by a machine. If the preference is presented upon load and not set by default and if the user has the option of selecting individual services (one at a time), accepting all, and denying all, then it can be deemed that the functionality is working as expected (as long as third-party services obey that scheme).

examples.1: Cookie banners are a classic example of personalization from the point of the page load and they can dictate the functionality of a website or application based on the choices made [as shown in this example](https://www.optimizely.com/).
examples.2: Being able to log into to a product allows customers to trigger decisions regarding their experience. [Apple Music](https://music.apple.com/us/new) (for example) uses the details of the user to make decisions based on their prior browsing habits.

procedure.1: Check that information is provided to indicate upon load to indicate preferences.
procedure.2: Check that the option to allow all, deny all, and select between providers is offered.
procedure.3: Check that information is provided identifying providers and describing the options carefully.
procedure.4: Check that preferences are remembered when navigating during the session.

techniques.title: Validate source code for semantic accuracy
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [3.7 Ensure code follows good semantic practices](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#ensure-code-follows-good-semantic-practices).

description.1: Ensure that HTML uses accurate semantics (Semantic HTML). Use the correct semantic element for the correct purpose and avoid common syntax mistakes that could be easily correctable. In terms of web sustainability it is important to have code that remains as likely to stay functional in the future as possible.
description.2: For machine testability, examining code for correct element use is a primary step. Other features found in validation services such as ensuring elements are closed correctly and that HTML entities are correctly marked up help avoid rare issues that might occur during the rendering process such as web browsers accidentally interpreting data incorrectly.

examples.1: The W3C provides markup validation services for [HTML](https://validator.w3.org/) and [CSS](https://jigsaw.w3.org/css-validator/), [JSON](https://jsonlint.com/), as well as [feeds](https://validator.w3.org/feed/) to identify potential issues with the code. These tools can work with direct input as well as files and direct input.
examples.2: Linting tools can check (and be configured) to help you find and resolve common errors either while you code or during an auditing process. There are linting tools available for languages like [HTML](https://markuplint.dev/), [CSS](https://stylelint.io/), [JavaScript](https://eslint.org/).

procedure.1: Check if the HTML, CSS, and other source code contains resolvable errors.
procedure.2: Check that any errors have been successfully linted and corrected.

techniques.title: Eliminate optional code to reduce the rendering impact
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [3.7 Ensure code follows good semantic practices](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#ensure-code-follows-good-semantic-practices).

description.1: Provide a mechanism for eliminating further redundancy from source code which may not be strictly required for semantic reasons but can help reduce the amount of data being transferred and thereby improve web performance. This can be done by removing any optional code from a document that will not affect the rendering of the page.
description.2: This technique is most useful when subscribing to performance budgets and attempting to reach the smallest file size possible is of critical importance to reach PPP targets. Such optional code removal can be identified by machine and recommendations for where optimization can occur can be provided but there may be occasions (as with minification) in non-production to retain the data.

examples.1: [This article by Jens Oliver Meiert](https://meiert.com/en/blog/optional-html/) provides details about some of the optional HTML elements you may wish to eliminate to reduce the amount of data being transferred to users during a page view session.
examples.2: [Browser Default Styles](https://browserdefaultstyles.com/) provides information about the CSS that a web browser will render to the user as a matter of course when an HTML element is created (therefore you do not need to repeat the statements).

procedure.1: Check that optional HTML elements that are unnecessary for rendering are removed.
procedure.2: Check that browser default styles are not repeated in the stylesheets.

techniques.title: Replace non-standard code with suitable alternative syntax
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [3.7 Ensure code follows good semantic practices](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#ensure-code-follows-good-semantic-practices).

description.1: Identify and eliminate any non-standard coding practices including but not limited to proprietary additions included by web browsers to test new functionality before potentially including it fully within the web browser (this is not so common today but remnants still exist). As older code is often not as highly optimized for performance, it can take longer to render and thrash hardware causing higher emissions so is worth resolving.
description.2: For machine testability, lists of non-standard syntax are available within common specifications which can be used to identify within source code. In addition, browser-specific code can be identified by its prefix or on lists of techniques and hacks to resolve browser bugs. If replacements for these techniques can be offered, provide them, otherwise recommend removal from your code.

examples.1: In the past, it was necessary to provide specific coding techniques (known as hacks) to ensure web browser compatibility. [Browser Hacks](http://browserhacks.com/), lists the various patterns used that could be solutions fit for removal.
examples.2: When [testing new features](https://ios404.com/), browsers had a habit of [prefixing their code](https://shouldiprefix.com/) in the past [behind flags](https://webstatus.dev/) to avoid breaking existing code. Lists of such prefixes can be found online as well as archaic proprietary HTML and CSS. Websites like [BCD Watch](https://bcd-watch.igalia.com/), [CSS Triggers](https://css-triggers.com/), [Runtime compatibility?](https://runtime-compat.unjs.io/), and [Web features explorer](https://web-platform-dx.github.io/web-features-explorer/) can help with compatibility testing.

procedure.1: Check that archaic proprietary specification additions are not included within the code.
procedure.2: Check that browser prefixes have been removed from CSS unless required for compatibility.
procedure.3: Check that no browser hacks exist unless they are required for compatibility.

techniques.title: Set scripts to load either asynchronously or deferred
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [3.8 Defer the loading of non-critical resources](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#defer-the-loading-of-non-critical-resources).

description.1: Provide a mechanism for JavaScript (and if possible StyleSheets) to be loaded asynchronously or deferred to avoid acting as render blocking events which can delay the loading of content. This will lessen the initial impact on users' hardware and thus can have PPP and web performance benefits which should be taken into account.
description.2: This technique is most useful when it is applied to all materials which will run upon the page load. In terms of testing for this technique, scripts can be identified by the attribute being provided within the HTML code. If the attribute is not provided, guidance can be offered to question if this was intentional or machine testing could analyze the code to verify if an issue will occur.

examples.1: [Chart.js](https://www.chartjs.org/docs/latest/samples/tooltip/content.html) is a library that allows you to easily produce complex charts within a website or application. It uses a combination of asynchronous and deferred loading to ensure the rendering does not block other content.

procedure.1: Check that all scripts are set to load with either the async or defer attributes unless necessary.
procedure.2: Check if CSS ([with the aid of JavaScript](https://www.holisticseo.digital/pagespeed/async-css/)) could benefit from asynchronous loading, and if so, do it.

techniques.title: Provide assets required at load with the correct delivery route
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [3.8 Defer the loading of non-critical resources](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#defer-the-loading-of-non-critical-resources).

description.1: Provide a mechanism for assets to be loaded at the correct time in the rendering process. With the ability to use preload, prefetch, and preconnect we can take resources such as web fonts and scripts that are necessary for the product or service to successfully be able to be displayed and ensure they are prioritized over other web assets.
description.2: Identifying that the asset being chosen for this mechanism is correct, linked to correctly, and has the right mechanism in place is of the highest priority for machine testers to ensure that the rendering process is not interrupted. If a low-priority object is given high priority it could delay the website or application from reaching the user and increase screen time.

examples.1: [Mightybytes](https://www.mightybytes.com/) uses DNS prefetching to ensure that fonts and JavaScript that are hosted on a third-party CDN service will be less likely to suffer render-blocking (as the host is readied before the content is requested).
examples.2: [Wholegrain Digital](https://www.wholegraindigital.com/) uses preloading on its web typography to avoid render blocking with several different weights being offered on the same typeface (all of which will be downloaded as the content is).

procedure.1: Check that preload, prefetch, and preconnect are used as appropriate in HTML documents.

techniques.title: Provide accurate social Metadata and Microdata
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [3.9 Provide information to help understand the usefulness of a page](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#provide-information-to-help-understand-the-usefulness-of-a-page).

description.1: Provide a mechanism for social networks and search engines to first identify your website or application and then to be able to showcase it successfully within their products and services. Because each social network and search engine has its own requirements, it will involve a combination of different metadata and semantic markup to achieve results.
description.2: For machine testability, toolmakers will need to maintain a list of the most popular products and services with which they wish to maintain compatibility. From there they will need to work through their requirements to ensure that the patterns expected are included within pages (and that they match the expectations of the providers so that results will ensure user findability).

examples.1: The [Small Tech Foundation](https://small-tech.org/) ensures that their content can be easily identified by third parties by providing metadata, open graph data, and microdata within the document header (that is easily machine-readable).
examples.2: Many social networks take advantage of the [OpenGraph Protocol](https://ogp.me/) including [Facebook](https://developers.facebook.com/docs/sharing/webmasters) and [X (formally Twitter)](https://developer.x.com/en/docs/x-for-websites/cards/overview/markup) in the HTML head. [Mastodon](https://joinmastodon.org/verification) uses the rel="me" attribute to identify websites with owners.

procedure.1: Check that the necessary OpenGraph data for Facebook is included within HTML.
procedure.2: Check that the necessary Twitter Card data is included within HTML for X.
procedure.3: Check that the necessary Mastodon link containing the rel attribute exists.
procedure.4: Check that other social networks have their criteria met or have links added.

techniques.title: Provide a robots.txt file that contains relevant indexing data
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [3.9 Provide information to help understand the usefulness of a page](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#provide-information-to-help-understand-the-usefulness-of-a-page).

description.1: Provide a mechanism of maintaining findability within products and services for search engines but also to attempt to (successfully or otherwise) reduce the amount of traffic from bad actors or unethical/unsustainable products that may impact your wider projects and service-users. This will be produced using the robots.txt document.
description.2: This technique requires that the robots.txt file be present within the base directory of a website and be formatted according to the commonly agreed upon Robots Exclusion Standard. For the success criteria, listing bad actors and unethical/unsustainable products is considered optional however if such a list can be maintained and adhered to, it is worthy of inclusion.

examples.1: [Google has a robots.txt file](Google Search Central has a document that provides working examples of the robots.txt file and the properties you should consider including within it (plus examples and details of how they will function).) of their own that identifies to search engines what pages should be included within search results. Naturally, you do not want to copy this file exactly but it may serve as inspiration!
