examples.2: [The Web Robots Pages website](https://www.robotstxt.org/robotstxt.html) is a resource dedicated to the robots exclusion standard and how it can be applied to websites including different examples and details about the robots.txt file structure.
examples.3: [Google Search Central](https://developers.google.com/search/docs/crawling-indexing/robots/robots_txt?hl=en) has a document that provides working examples of the robots.txt file and the properties you should consider including within it (plus examples and details of how they will function).

procedure.1: Check for the existence of a robots.txt within the base directory of a website or application.
procedure.2: Check that the document is well formed and contains the correct property/value pairs.
procedure.3: Check for a list of blacklisted bad actors and unsustainable products.

techniques.title: Add signposting within the page to direct users and accessibility aids
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [3.9 Provide information to help understand the usefulness of a page](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#provide-information-to-help-understand-the-usefulness-of-a-page).

description.1: Provide mechanisms to assist the user with finding and navigating through content within the page or application. This can come in the form of links that allow you to bypass blocks of content, which is especially useful when large vocal areas of navigation or other content exist. It could also be in the form of keyboard shortcuts that activate certain features within a complex application rather than having to click multiple steps.
description.2: Machine testability for such features can identify events within JavaScript or features that use common patterns in code that are recognized as helpful signposting features. If such features are present then the success criteria can be marked as compliant but if none are found it could be an indicator, especially in complex websites or applications that such features are needed.

examples.1: [WebAim has a great article](https://webaim.org/techniques/skipnav/) describing the details relating to skip links [as does Jim Thatcher](https://www.jimthatcher.com/skipnav.htm), both include plenty of useful visual examples and situations to work with when designing a custom solution of your own.
examples.2: Smashing Magazine published a [two](https://www.smashingmagazine.com/2022/11/guide-keyboard-accessibility-html-css-part1/) [part](https://www.smashingmagazine.com/2022/11/guide-keyboard-accessibility-javascript-part2/) guide to keyboard accessibility which included HTML, CSS, and JavaScript and covered not only skip links but also provided keyboard-based accessibility aids.

procedure.1: Check that the project can be successfully navigated using the keyboard.
procedure.2: Check that the tabindex order of the content makes logical, navigable sense.
procedure.3: Check that skip links exist to guide accessibility tools through content.
procedure.4: Check that keyboard shortcuts are well documented and work as expected.
procedure.5: Check that signposting within pages are well described, and work as directed.

techniques.title: Ensure that form inputs correctly match and validate content expectations
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [3.10 Validate form errors and account for tooling requirements](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#validate-form-errors-and-account-for-tooling-requirements).

description.1: Ensure that input types correctly match the type of content being placed within them, that content types like passwords are handled in a way that users can easily reveal them, and that the patterns attribute is used correctly to help reduce errors during data entry. In doing so, problematic friction encountered during form filling can be reduced as can erroneous submissions.
description.2: Machine testability for this criteria will involve analyzing the components of forms to ensure they are well formed and that (for example) any regular expressions used in patterns will not produce an erroneous result. It is also important that functionality within forms perform well on mobile devices as well as desktop so consideration must be given to the choice of input for tasks.

examples.1: [This article from TheGood](https://thegood.com/insights/form-design-examples/) showcases multiple examples of great form design not only from the point of the user experience but also in the development to ensure that the ability to make mistakes is reduced.

procedure.1: Check that the input type matches the expected content type.
procedure.2: Check that the use of the pattern attribute does not prevent correct input.
procedure.3: Check that regular expressions are correctly formed and do not equate errors.
procedure.4: Check that password fields can be made visible to allow for recognition.
procedure.5: Check that one input type will function well on mobile devices over another.

techniques.title: Ensure that form elements are correctly labeled
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [3.10 Validate form errors and account for tooling requirements](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#validate-form-errors-and-account-for-tooling-requirements).

description.1: Provide a mechanism for accessibility tooling to be able to accurately describe the content of form features and to provide visual aids for users aiming to identify what information is required to be entered. This technique requires all interactive elements within the form to have an associated label to describe the purpose and/or role of the item.
description.2: Labels should be presented directly beside the element in question to imply association and if multiple associations are required, a grouping element with a label can be provided. Machines should be able to identify the relationship between the label and the object through the syntax and if objects without labels exist, a failure statement can be flagged up.

examples.1: [This CodePen example](https://codepen.io/sushma-io/pen/zYbOREe) clearly has all interactive elements within the form correctly labeled and additionally goes the extra step by using input types to help reduce the chances of errors occurring during data entry.

procedure.1: Check that all interactive form components are correctly labeled.

techniques.title: Reduce issues within data entry with manual third-party content
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [3.10 Validate form errors and account for tooling requirements](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#validate-form-errors-and-account-for-tooling-requirements).

description.1: Provide a mechanism in which users can easily take content from third-party sources and use it within your product or service. Techniques such as the ability to paste into forms or the ability to drag and drop can act as shortcuts to avoid retyping or recreating (using system resources) which may be energy-intensive or time-intensive for the user.
description.2: Identifying mechanisms that may prevent the ability to import third-party content such as blocking pasting content or disabling the ability to drag and drop should be detected and flagged (unless a reason for this can be justified within the code). Mechanisms that aid the ability to import third-party content such as import or paste buttons should be actively encouraged.

examples.1: These CodePen examples of [log in](https://codepen.io/colorlib/pen/rxddKy) and [registration](https://codepen.io/RajRajeshDn/pen/QWwypRy) forms do not inhibit the user from pasting content from third-party sources which allows for fast data entry if the information is stored elsewhere.

procedure.1: Check that the ability to paste content is uninhibited (no onpaste="return false;").
procedure.2: Check that the ability to drag and drop third-party content can be achieved successfully.
procedure.3: Check that import options are provided if the above two options are unavailable or fail.

techniques.title: Ensure that the required HTML elements are included
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [3.11 Structure metadata for machine readability](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#structure-metadata-for-machine-readability).

description.1: Ensure that minimum required features are present to render a website or application correctly. This includes a Doctype and a series of core HTML elements. While a page can technically render without them it is considered bad practice to not include these features.
description.2: For machine testability, the ability to identify a DocType (and the version of HTML being rendered), plus ensuring that the necessary base HTML elements are present is script detectable. This can be done via the validation process, manually, or automated to ensure pages render correctly and avoid triggering quirks mode (that will affect the visual rendering of the website or application).

examples.1: Courtney Thomas back in 2018 [created a great article](https://medium.com/@cortneythomas/laymans-coding-what-is-the-minimum-html-you-need-for-a-website-eda987b02622) that showcased the minimum HTML that is required for any website or application (though [as Josh Buchea notes](https://htmlhead.dev/), the viewport meta tag should also be there).

procedure.1: Check that the document includes a well-formed DocType.
procedure.2: Check that the page or application includes the required HTML elements.
procedure.3: Check that the page or application includes valid links to CSS and JavaScript assets (optional).
procedure.4: Check that the HTML includes the viewport META element for handheld devices.

techniques.title: Provide relevant metadata using a recognized scheme
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [3.11 Structure metadata for machine readability](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#structure-metadata-for-machine-readability).

description.1: Provide the necessary metadata within the head of your website or application to ensure that search engines can index your content correctly. You can use several different mechanisms to achieve this as several different formatting schemes have been provided over the years and they have varying levels of support by different search providers.
description.2: To enhance the findability of your content (which will reduce time being wasted by users trying to locate you), having a well-formatted series of metadata is critical. As such, testing should focus on determining whether basic meta tags are used or if another format is being used to serve data. Once detected, identify if the tags are recognized, if they are not in common use or have been deprecated by a provider, it is worth requesting removal for the data savings.

examples.1: The WHATWG not only has within the [HTML specification](https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/semantics.html) a list of recognized elements that can provide contextual information about the page, but it also has a wiki that lists [proprietary META tags](https://wiki.whatwg.org/wiki/MetaExtensions).

procedure.1: Check that the HTML document contains a description META element of [between 50 and 150 characters](https://moz.com/learn/seo/meta-description).
procedure.2: Check that the HTML document contains additional metadata from a recognized scheme.

techniques.title: Ensure content is structured using Microdata
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [3.11 Structure metadata for machine readability](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#structure-metadata-for-machine-readability).

description.1: Provide mechanisms for search engines and social networks (and sometimes even users and web browsers!) to take context-rich content from your website or application and re-use it for the benefit of your product or service elsewhere. Structuring your content successfully can take place (like metadata) using one of several formats.
description.2: Because microdata uses hooks that attach to existing HTML to make it easy to identify (for search engines and third-parties), this will also make it easy to identify for machine testability. Using a pattern library of these various structural features you can not only show users how content could be used but using heuristics identify other content that might benefit from it.

examples.1: [Schema](https://schema.org/) is a database of common patterns that have been formed using microdata. It is a huge library and could be potentially helpful in describing certain components in a way that search engines can recognize.

procedure.1: Check that content is correctly marked up using microdata, microformats, etc.
procedure.2: Check for external RDFa assets that may contain rich metadata.

techniques.title: Ensure CSS preference media queries are correctly applied
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [3.12 Use sustainability beneficial user preference media queries](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#use-sustainability-beneficial-user-preference-media-queries).

description.1: Provide mechanisms through CSS that adhere to the user's preferences regarding how they may choose to browse a website or application. While some queries that exist in the language will hold little sustainability value, others could have PPP benefits through accessibility (societal factors), or environmental (reducing hardware or data usage).
description.2: Each of the preference queries can be machine-identified through scripts and therefore can be tested against firstly for browser support, and secondly that the project provides some kind of environmental consequence for using the query that will benefit the user and/or the ecosystem. The value of such queries being applied could be measured by triggering or emulating them.

examples.1: [Hidde de Vries](https://hidde.blog/) has a dark mode toggle that using a mixture of CSS preference queries and JavaScript allows dark or light mode to either be user-triggered or run at the default (it is non-invasively implemented).
examples.2: [These examples](https://webkit.org/blog-files/prefers-reduced-motion/prm.htm) provided by the Webkit team showcase how reduced motion (when enabled) can prevent excess movement. Though a toggle ([such as this by Michelle Barker](https://codepen.io/smashingmag/pen/porEQLB)) could provide [added use-cases](https://www.smashingmagazine.com/2021/10/respecting-users-motion-preferences/).

procedure.1: Check for preference queries and that the effect they produce is beneficial.
procedure.2: Check for manual override toggles or preferences within the page.
procedure.3: Check for alternative styles if paged media or scripting is disabled.

techniques.title: Test against network speeds and visual resolution breakpoints
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [3.13 Ensure layouts work for different devices and requirements](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#ensure-layouts-work-for-different-devices-and-requirements).

description.1: Ensure that your product or service can be classified as device-adaptable (responsively designed) to hopefully assure the widest remit of device types, and at least some degree of visual compatibility with your website or application. While there are many ways to approach this task, this technique is focused on connection speeds and the potential window size.
description.2: Because connection speeds can vary based on a whole range of factors (and cannot be aligned with averages due to location, mobile vs home, connection quality, etc), multiple speed ranges should be machine tested against. The same can be said for window sizes as while resolutions are common to certain devices, browsers can be resized, and unusual device types do also exist therefore CSS fluid scaling and visual breakpoints should be utilized.

examples.1: [WebPageTest](https://www.webpagetest.org/) allows you to check how a product or service will perform at different speeds (including custom profiles you set up). Running such tests can identify if a product or service takes too long to load.
examples.2: Browser developer tools can test a website at various dimensions (on desktop) and by manually resizing the browser window with the developer tools open (and rulers toggled in Firefox), you can identify breakpoints where the design of the site requires code solutions.

procedure.1: Check that the website or application performs well on a variety of network speeds.
procedure.2: Check that the product or service visually does not break when resized at multiple window sizes.

techniques.title: Provide progressive enhancement feature testing within projects
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [3.13 Ensure layouts work for different devices and requirements](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#ensure-layouts-work-for-different-devices-and-requirements).

description.1: Provide a mechanism for providing features within your product or service only if they are supported and if not, providing alternatives. This can be done using feature detection and progressive enhancement which should be used as a priority over graceful degradation (as it is better to add useful extras rather than patch-critical - but broken content).
description.2: Machine testability for feature testing should identify any code within the product or service that relies upon newer functionality lacking a level of web browser support (either in competing products or older versions), testing should occur and errors should be handled. Furthermore, if technologies are not supported, the fallback mechanism should allow a basic project to run.

examples.1: Jeremy Keith's website ([Adactio](https://adactio.com/)) is a great example of progressive enhancement in action. It works if JavaScript, CSS, or even images are disabled (though naturally, the visuals can suffer as a result!).

procedure.1: Check that the website or application can function if JavaScript is disabled.
procedure.2: Check that the page is still functional if an older browser version with older JavaScript and CSS version is used.
procedure.3: Check that the product or service is still functional if CSS is disabled.
procedure.4: Check that the product or service is still functional if images or media are disabled.

tests.expectedResults: Expectation of the above is dependent on the task but should aim to be true unless necessary.

techniques.title: Configure your project around carbon-aware situations
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [3.13 Ensure layouts work for different devices and requirements](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#ensure-layouts-work-for-different-devices-and-requirements).

description.1: Provide a mechanism for identifying when the project might be at its most resource or energy-intensive (either at the consumer level or the system level - or both), and then decision make to delay or alter when a heavy script or operation occurs to perform it when there are fewer users or when the user is causing less hardware intensive activity.
description.2: For machine testability, this could be particularly tricky to implement as it will rely on data to which the project owner will need to gain access such as when user numbers are at their lowest (or when the task can be achieved at its quickest). This may require internal access, but if granted the use of such data could allow for redesigning the site to perform better during busy periods.

examples.1: [Electricity Maps](https://app.electricitymaps.com/map?solar=false&remote=true&wind=false) provides an application that could be utilized to help make decisions as to where data is being served (based upon the intensity and level of carbon-free energy being offered in particular regions).

procedure.1: Check if operations can be built to function using carbon-aware technologies or resources.
procedure.2: Check if operations can be processed or shifted to occur during less carbon-intensive periods.

techniques.title: Provide low-impact, possibly delayed methods of interaction
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [3.13 Ensure layouts work for different devices and requirements](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#ensure-layouts-work-for-different-devices-and-requirements).

description.1: Provide a mechanism for interacting with a website or application using more usual methods, but methods that often will have a reduced overall impact (such as having a reduced energy requirement). These indirect methods such as syndication feeds or the browser reader view can even eliminate the heavy impact of rendering that can affect hardware.
description.2: This technique is most useful when it can be easily recognized by users and can be used instead of having to visit the main website or application. In terms of machine testability, if these low-impact techniques use a common pattern and that pattern can be easily identified within the source code then naturally it can be identified as such and can be marked as meeting the criteria.

examples.1: Quick Response (QR) codes are a great example of objects that can be included not only online but offline in branding to trigger both links and in-app actions with only the impact of rendering the object (or printing it).
examples.2: Smartwatches may have some Internet connectivity. Due to the small screen size, they will have a low energy output but also a small battery so having a low-fidelity version of a website can be really useful.

procedure.1: Check for low-impact interaction methods such as QR codes, smartwatch layouts, or voice assistant tooling.

techniques.title: Optimize a codebase through rewriting for performance
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [3.14 Use Standards-based JavaScript and APIs](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#use-standards-based-javascript-and-apis).

description.1: Improve the quality of JavaScript code by examining the contents and identifying any issues that could be deemed a matter of sustainability which could trigger a large load upon hardware resources (and thus put a strain on battery charge cycles). In addition to this, matters of accessibility and performance with such code can be considered.
description.2: To meet the success criteria, rewriting for performance should only be done if the act does not cost more in effort (and creator impact) than it gains in impact. For machine testability, it is critical that such actions within scripting use tools at their disposal (libraries, patterns, even AI) to heuristically identify any issues that may require resolution within the project's source code.

examples.1: Solid.js author Ryan Carniato created [this thoughtful post](https://javascript.plainenglish.io/how-we-wrote-the-fastest-javascript-ui-frameworks-a96f2636431e) in 2019 about how they went about integrating web performance in their framework-building processes. It is based on a widely recognized JavaScript study.
examples.2: The team at Astro [used open data to examine](https://astro.build/blog/2023-web-framework-performance-report/) the performance ratings of various competing JavaScript frameworks to identify the differences between physical and real-world metrics (there are lots of useful charts).

procedure.1: Check that existing code has been rewritten to be less process intensive, etc.
procedure.2: Check that any existing tooling is considered sustainable and/or performant.
procedure.3: Check if JavaScript frameworks can be replaced with others that are more performant.
procedure.4: If frameworks can be replaced, check that they are replaced.

techniques.title: Ensure JavaScript APIs are correctly applied
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [3.14 Use Standards-based JavaScript and APIs](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#use-standards-based-javascript-and-apis).

description.1: Provide mechanisms through JavaScript that minimize the user's energy consumption by either optimizing the performance of the website or application itself or improving functionality in such a way that it reduces the utilization of resources when they are not required by the user. Some JavaScript APIs can have explicit sustainability benefits, while others may improve other PPP benefits through accessibility (societal factors).
description.2: Each of the JavaScript APIs can be machine-identified through scripts and therefore can be tested against firstly for browser support, and secondly that the project provides some environmental consequence for using the script that will benefit the user and/or the ecosystem. The value of such scripts could be measured by triggering or emulating them.

examples.1: [MDN Provides a list of Web APIs](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API) that can be implemented ([with varying levels of browser support](https://whatwebcando.today/). Some of these provide enhanced functionality to the end-user, and others may tuned to provide the ecodesign benefits that will give your product or service an edge.
examples.2: Custom APIs such as our [WSG JSON API](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/guidelines.json) ([source](https://github.com/w3c/sustainableweb-wsg/blob/main/guidelines.json)) can be used within your product or service to provide actionable sustainability information to your users that is maintained and kept up-to-date.

procedure.1: Check for JavaScript APIs and that the effect they produce is beneficial.
procedure.2: Check that the API has enough support to be progressively implemented.
procedure.3: Check that the implementation cost is not greater than the amount it offsets.
procedure.4: If the API is dependent on third-parties, ensure they are sustainable and resilient.

techniques.title: Ensure all vulnerabilities are removed and code is Linted
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [3.15 Ensure that your code is secure](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#ensure-that-your-code-is-secure).

description.1: Scan the website or application's code for issues that may otherwise potentially leave a product or service vulnerable to exploitation. This will not only include first-party code that is created by the project owners but third-party tooling imported. Any third-party library or framework found to contain harmful code should be removed before production.
description.2: Because this can occur at both the client-side and server-side internal access may be required if server-side scanning is wished to be included within machine testability, however within the scope of the success criteria, if internal access is not available or permitted, testing the code using known methods and scanning client-side code for harmful techniques should help with passing.

examples.1: RayGun [provides a great article](https://raygun.com/blog/js-security-vulnerabilities-best-practices/) about vulnerabilities and best practices when working with JavaScript. Some of the things mentioned are covered within the WSG in other sections, all others can be followed here.
examples.2: [Snyk](https://snyk.io/) is one of the most well-known providers of data regarding code vulnerabilities. They can be integrated within existing tooling or you can browse their [database of known security issues](https://security.snyk.io/) to be aware of.

procedure.1: Check the product or service for vulnerabilities within your code, ensuring they are resolved.

techniques.title: Identify and remove unused packages and dependencies
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [3.16 Use dependencies appropriately and ensure maintenance](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#use-dependencies-appropriately-and-ensure-maintenance).

description.1: Provide a mechanism for identifying if a library or framework is currently in use and if not, remove the said tooling and its unused dependencies from the production code. This will help reduce the PPP burden of the website as less bloat will reach the user which can have a large impact if they are on a low-powered device or a restricted data plan.
description.2: For machine testability, internal access will be required to determine if web developers or creators will require specific tooling within a project. If internal access is given, the package.json file is an ideal place to locate the packages being requested and these can be compared against the public-facing website to identify redundancy in the toolchain process.

examples.1: An application that removes functionality due to poor uptake no longer requires certain packages to contain scripts that were dedicated to running that function alone. Such dependencies have become redundant.

procedure.1: Check if a package.json has been submitted for identifying packages.
procedure.2: If so, use that. Otherwise, check the source code for potential orphan references.

techniques.title: Implement modularized frameworks and libraries
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [3.16 Use dependencies appropriately and ensure maintenance](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#use-dependencies-appropriately-and-ensure-maintenance).

description.1: Provide a mechanism for determining how much of a library of framework you require for your website or application to function, and then requesting just that modularized segment to reduce the overall payload and load on the user's hardware during rendering. This is especially critical for third-party scripting but is also useful for CSS.
description.2: Machine testability should attempt to identify when third-party libraries are present within a codebase and if that framework or library supports the ability to load a lightweight or modular version of its features (thereby only loading what you require, when you require it), ensure that the project in question does so rather than loading an un-optimal "fully-loaded" version of the project.

examples.1: [Bundlephobia](https://bundlephobia.com/) and [pkg-size](https://pkg-size.dev/) allow you to find the true size of a package on NPM by calculating not just the size of the item you wish to install but all of the dependencies the item requires to function.

procedure.1: Check the package size to determine at what size breaking into modular components should occur.
procedure.2: Check the function sizes to identify if refactoring to smaller functions should also occur.

techniques.title: Ensure that dependencies are verified as up-to-date
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [3.16 Use dependencies appropriately and ensure maintenance](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#use-dependencies-appropriately-and-ensure-maintenance).

description.1: Ensure that the deliverables are current and up-to-date, thereby providing any necessary security patches or bug fixes that are required to remain operational. This is especially true when a website or application is dependent on third-party libraries or frameworks and has a complex toolchain. As such, verifying the maintenance status of work is critical.
description.2: To machine test or verify the dependency chain of a project, the source code of a project should identify (by filename or URL) the project and version. If during the tree shaking or production process all notifications of what third-party code has been used have been removed, internal access will be required to access the package.json (except heuristic fingerprinting of packages).

examples.1: As you would expect, the [jQuery project website](https://jquery.com/) uses the latest version of the jQuery framework. Because it is a regularly maintained project and can afford rapid update cycles, it stays current and up-to-date.

procedure.1: Check if a package.json has been submitted for identifying packages.
procedure.2: If so, use that. Otherwise, check the source code for package version data.
procedure.3: Check that all packages are at least non-breaking (minor) current if not major release current releases.

techniques.title: Provide the expected website assets in your base directory
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [3.17 Include expected and beneficial files](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#include-expected-and-beneficial-files).

description.1: Ensure that the non-HTML files that are expected to be located within the base directory of a website can firstly be found and secondly are correctly formatted (using the right syntax) and match the expectations of the product or service that requires them to benefit the user with a better user experience, increased accessibility, and sustainability.
description.2: For machine testability, tooling should aim to identify that the listed files are provided (if not flag these justifying the need for their inclusion). If they are included they should be examined to ensure they are semantically correct, especially if they are formed using a strict language such as XML. If they fail to validate correctly errors should constitute a failure to meet the success criteria.

examples.1: Amazon has a highly recognizable brand and they [provide a favicon](https://www.amazon.com/favicon.ico) in the base of their website so that when people visit them, their icon will show correctly in the top left of the tab or window (browser dependent).
examples.2: Developer tool Can I Use [provide an opensearch.xml file](https://caniuse.com/opensearch.xml) in the base of their website so that if people visit their project, users can rapidly search the website in the future using a keyword and tab combination.

procedure.1: Check the base directory for a favicon in 1616, 3232, and 4848 format.
procedure.2: Check the base directory for a well-formed robots.txt document.
procedure.3: Check the base directory for a well-formed opensearch.xml and sitemap.xml file.
procedure.4: Check the base directory for a well-formed site.webmanifest document.
procedure.5: Check that the links contained within these documents do not contain errors.

techniques.title: Provide beneficial plaintext website assets in the expected locations
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [3.17 Include expected and beneficial files](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#include-expected-and-beneficial-files).

description.1: Provide a mechanism for adding useful contextual information to a website or application within recognized locations in plaintext format (so that it does not impact the rest of the product or service). These standardized formats each have a defined beneficial purpose and are considered to be low-impact (sustainably speaking) so are safe to include.
description.2: This technique is most useful when the assets are formatted as per their specification for purposes of readability, it is how individuals and machines will be expected to understand them. For machine testability, using heuristics to scan for recognized features within the text should help you identify the instructions or any features of note that could be weighed in calculations.

examples.1: [WordPress has an ads.txt file](https://wordpress.com/ads.txt) at the base of their website, that contains details of the advertisers they work with (and tries to increase transparency by revealing where impressions are purchased and resold).
examples.2: Web Developer Sarah Tamsin has a [fun example of a humans.txt file](https://sarahtamsin.com/humans.txt) that provides some witty content and a few basic details about her (plus an ASCII image that makes for a nice easter egg bonus feature).
examples.3: The security.txt specification writers have [created a basic example](https://securitytxt.org/.well-known/security.txt) of what could be included within the file. As you can see from the example, the location of the document differs from other plaintext examples.

procedure.1: If you have advertising, check that the base directory contains a well-formed ads.txt document.
procedure.2: Check that the base directory contains a well-formed security.txt and robots.txt document.
procedure.3: Check that the base directory contains a well-formed carbon.txt and humans.txt document (optional).

techniques.title: Replace outdated syntax with suitable alternatives
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [3.18 Avoid using deprecated, proprietary, or outdated code](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#avoid-using-deprecated-proprietary-or-outdated-code).

description.1: Identify deprecated code, technologies and web standards that may be in use but have been superseded by newer technologies and web standards. In certain cases, the standards in use may still be actively supported by browsers and if there is a sustainability reason to retain the feature, continue. Otherwise, updating the code should be considered to ensure longevity and sustainability.
description.2: For machine testability, deprecations in languages can also be found within specifications from providers like the W3C. Documentation providers like MDN also provide extremely thorough coverage of syntax that has been deprecated such as within HTML, CSS, and JavaScript. If replacements for any techniques can be offered, provide them, otherwise recommend removal from your code.

examples.1: The [Space Jam website](https://www.spacejam.com/1996/) is considered a classic piece of 90s Internet design with its total disregard for function over form, but if you look at the code - it gets even uglier with table-based layouts and deprecated code
examples.2: The [Web Design Museum](https://www.webdesignmuseum.org/flash-websites) houses a showcase of screenshots of websites that were built using the proprietary technology Adobe Flash. Along with Java Applets and Microsoft Silverlight they now no longer work.

procedure.1: Check that the project does not contain any outdated layout techniques (such as table-based design).
procedure.2: Check that the website or application does not contain deprecated syntax features.
procedure.3: Check if the existing product or service uses outdated technologies (VML/P3P, etc) and if so recommend replacements (X3D/POWDER, etc).
procedure.4: Check for proprietary web plugins (like Flash) and remove them until a replacement can be created.

techniques.title: Encourage the use of more sustainable creation toolchains
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [3.19 Use the most efficient solution for your service](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#use-the-most-efficient-solution-for-your-service).

description.1: Provide a mechanism of choice when creators decide how to build their product or service. This technique aims to identify how they created their product or service (if possible) and make recommendations based on the sustainability of such methods. Build steps and tooling add additional complexity to a project and this should be weighed against other factors (such as individual/team ability) to enable sustainable creation toolchains.
description.2: For machine testability, internal access may be required if no traces of the creation tool have been left in the production code. If the production code does however contain fingerprints of the tool that created it, recommendations can be made to prioritize static over dynamic and flat-static over generated-static as reducing the processing effort on servers and client machines is meaningful.

examples.1: [Jekyll](https://jekyllrb.com/) is one of many solutions that exist as a solution for producing a website - in this case, it uses markdown and bundles the plaintext into a finalized pure HTML state (which should have a low carbon output).

procedure.1: Check for the tool used for creation and determine its sustainability.
procedure.2: If it has a low impact, continue. Otherwise, flag for replacement.

techniques.title: Test all third-party resources for sustainability impacts
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [3.19 Use the most efficient solution for your service](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#use-the-most-efficient-solution-for-your-service).

description.1: Provide a mechanism for testing third-party plugins, extensions, and themes (if such devices are used within a product or service's creation process) for any sustainability impacts they may have. These often are included within CMS software and are external assets that can add overheads to the website or application being rendered.
description.2: For machine testability, many CMS products provide trace details of included features within the source code of a page (as conditional comments) due to these having to be loaded as third-party resources. Internal access may be required to get a full picture of everything being loaded. Third-party resources should be tested against the WSG separately to identify sustainability issues.

examples.1: When using WordPress as their primary content management system, they often want to have a distinctive layout for their blog or website. As such they will install a custom theme, and its code with sustainability impacts will be imported into the total bundle size. So be careful what you choose!

procedure.1: Check if any third-party resources exist within the page or application.
procedure.2: If internal access is required to verify resource usage, grant it.
procedure.3: Check that component against the WSG for its sustainability compliance.
procedure.4: Check if high-impact third-party resources offer self-hosted alternatives.
procedure.5: Check that self-hosted alternatives are used if provided.

techniques.title: Ensure the latest version of a syntax language is being used
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [3.20 Use the latest stable language version](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#use-the-latest-stable-language-version).

description.1: Ensure that the product or service is making use of the latest version of the chosen syntax language. As with keeping dependencies up-to-date, having the latest version of a syntax language can have sustainability benefits in terms of performance and security enhancements as well as useful, optimized new features so it is worthwhile.
description.2: For machine testability, it will be difficult to verify the latest version of a syntax language is being used because, for security reasons (to avoid exploitation), most servers will not give out such information. As such, internal access will be required or a mixture of feature detection, source code examination, and the potential for asking the user of the tooling questions to establish versions.

examples.1: PHP provides a list of the [supported](https://www.php.net/supported-versions.php) and [unsupported](https://www.php.net/releases/index.php) versions of their programming language. You should be able to manage updates and upgrades within a hosting provider's control panel (if required).

procedure.1: Check that the version of a programming language being used is the latest.

techniques.title: Replace code that can instead use more efficient native APIs
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [3.21 Take advantage of native features and functionality](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#take-advantage-of-native-features-and-functionality).

description.1: First identify and then determine if custom JavaScript functions could be replaced with a more optimal and established native API call. This will also apply to custom element creation over using established native features to the browser. With the evolution of JavaScript, the opportunity to optimize code with newer cleaner techniques occurs regularly.
description.2: It is preferable to measure both the newer method of implementation with the older method to identify if one provides a more optimized (via performance and sustainability metrics) implementation than the other before replacement. Also, this technique is most useful when considering if the custom component provides additional functionality that the native component does not and if such features weigh up beneficially against the cleaner native implementation.

examples.1: MDN provides a [great list of native web APIs](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API) for JavaScript including the interfaces that can be used to call them. Within each of those items, you will find detailed documentation along with examples of usage.

procedure.1: Check if the benefits of a native browser control exceed creating a custom element.
procedure.2: Check if a native API exists that could replace custom calls, methods, or functions.
procedure.3: In either of these instances, if the answer is yes, check that the native option is used.

techniques.title: Publicly disclose relevant sustainability metrics to users
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [4.1 Choose a sustainable service provider](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#choose-a-sustainable-service-provider).

description.1: Ensure that anyone who wishes to compile an impact statement (as a consumer of your services) based on conditions such as PUE, WUE, and CUE can calculate the necessary energy utilization of a provider using each of the available data based upon any variables required. Making important metrics publicly visible to both customers and users, increases awareness, reduces the potential for greenwashing, and allows service providers to report with proof of compliance.
description.2: For machine testability, this would require each customer account (of a hosting provider) to be equipped with a publicly visible stats page indicating resource utilization, including useful information on variables like CPU, GPU, RAM, and data usage, plus a calculation on equivalent water or other consumable resource utilization. This can be linked to from within the service status page. In addition, the methodology behind the calculations should also be provided in a centralized location.

examples.1: [OVHCloud](https://corporate.ovhcloud.com/en/sustainability/environment/) and [Opcore](https://pue.dc5.opcore.eu/en/) both showcase different ways of displaying data about their environmental impact and notably, the variables that make up that number (with calculations and individual metrics provided). Both dashboards and sustainability panels are equally useful tools for showcasing such information.
examples.2: A service provider could make the internal resource usage stats page that comes with many hosting packages publicly visible (upon request of the website or application provider), and include sustainability data within.

procedure.1: Check that the provider has made available relevant hosting metrics publicly.
procedure.2: Check that the PUE, WUE, and CUE are each listed for each data center.
procedure.3: Check that individual servers provide live CPU, GPU, RAM, and data use tracking.
procedure.4: Check that logging of past values over time is provided for calculating emissions.

techniques.title: Ensure that the project is hosted on a sustainable platform
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [4.1 Choose a sustainable service provider](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#choose-a-sustainable-service-provider).

description.1: Verify that the product or service is being served through a sustainable provider. If the hosting provider (for example) generates its electricity from carbon-free energy and can document other intensity reduction techniques (such as using natural cooling and offering auto-scaling packages), this can contribute towards passing the success criteria.
description.2: Because many factors can go towards how sustainable a provider is, machine testing will need to be vigilant in accounting for several variables. As such, using an established directory of sustainable hosts could be one way to pass or fail, or running validation checks against factors that affect the sustainability of services could be another (this may require internal access or knowledge).

examples.1: The [Green Web Directory](https://www.thegreenwebfoundation.org/tools/directory/) from the Green Software Foundation provides a list of sustainable providers of hosting (based on their own criteria). If a service is listed in a reputable list as this, it may meet the success criteria.
examples.2: [Krystal](https://krystal.io/green) is an example of a provider offering detailed information about their sustainability process including their B-Corporation status, and the schemes they have signed up with to validate and reinforce their claims.

procedure.1: Check that the hosting provider has a sustainability statement.
procedure.2: Check that the hosting is powered by 100% carbon-free energy.
procedure.3: Check that the hosting platform does not use carbon credits to offset its energy requirements.
procedure.4: Check for recognized green initiatives that the platform may be subscribed to.

techniques.title: Ensure that the project uses a sustainable domain registrar
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [4.1 Choose a sustainable service provider](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#choose-a-sustainable-service-provider).

description.1: Ensure that emissions reports are published, with adequate frequency, considering (if possible) changes to DNS, subdomain allocation, multiple domain ownership, or other conditions that may impact the scope results. Also, be sure to provide calculations on an individual and collective domain level (where situations allow) to enable the best overview possible of total impact and most impactful domains. Having these metrics available for customers will increase public awareness, and allow registrants to meet reporting obligations as part of their compliance requirements.
description.2: For machine testability customer accounts should have a method to view changes in emissions, this would require an account (of a registrar) to be made accessible within tooling or for generalized statistics that account for the total amount of users to be made publicly visible (so averages can be used). This would help estimate and account for the impact of domain use based on TLD choice and other variables that will be relevant to the measurement criteria. The methodology behind the calculations should also be provided in a centralized location.

examples.1: The [Eco Registry](https://go.eco/news/climate-reporting-for-eco-domains/) provides climate reports for customers, allowing them to get an estimate of the emissions from operating the domain name over the lifetime of the registration period.

procedure.1: Check that the provider has made available relevant impact metrics publicly.
procedure.2: Account for factors that may affect domain impact (such as number of domains in use).
procedure.3: Check that logging of past values over time is provided for calculating emissions.

techniques.title: Provide caching responses to optimize page reloads
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [4.2 Optimize caching with offline access supported](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#optimize-caching-with-offline-access-supported).

description.1: Provide a mechanism for websites and applications to ensure that content is cached for the correct length of time, with the intention of reusability. Because certain types of content will change and need to be reloaded more frequently than others, it makes sense to cache those that change the least for the longest period (to reduce data transfer rates).
description.2: For machine testability, identifying cache response times for various file formats can be done by checking the cache-control headers for various files as they are requested from the server. If the length of time the content is being held does not appear to be long enough (or is too long for dynamic content), then recommendations can be made to improve the used formula.

examples.1: For individuals who use content management systems, some plugins offer [automatic caching management](https://www.wpbeginner.com/plugins/best-wordpress-caching-plugins/). They each have a range of features but essentially allow you to automate the caching process.

procedure.1: Check the cache-control header of each file has the correct length set.

techniques.title: Identify the potential for PWAs and other useful features
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [4.2 Optimize caching with offline access supported](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#optimize-caching-with-offline-access-supported).

description.1: Identify if techniques could be used to increase the performance within the user experience. Examples of this could include identifying if cookies could (and should) be used within an interface or if the website or application could be transformed into a progressive web application to provide advantages (project-wide) such as offline availability.
description.2: Machine testability to identify existing features is relatively straightforward as it simply requires identifying through the source code where cookies, local database requests, service, or web workers are implemented and ensuring that they are both proportionate and correctly marked up. If these do not exist it will require analyzing the page (or components) for potential opportunities for use.

examples.1: [Gmail](https://workspace.google.com/intl/en_us/gmail/) makes sense as a progressive web application because if the Internet connection is lost (at any point), being able to continue using certain features without losing your progress is critical to functionality.
examples.2: [NPM](https://www.npmjs.com/login) saves information about your membership login locally (as do many other providers) to avoid needing to re-enter your details repeatedly. This is a useful feature as it increases a product's perceived performance.

procedure.1: Check if cookies are in use and, whether they can be added, removed, or replaced.
procedure.2: Check if local data storage is being used and, whether it can be added, removed, or replaced.
procedure.3: Check if a PWA or other worker functions are in use and, whether they can be added or removed.
procedure.4: If a PWA exists, check for a well-formed manifest file, an icon, and semantically correct JavaScript.

techniques.title: Ensure that files are compressed correctly before serving
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [4.3 Compress files where it is beneficial](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#compress-files-where-it-is-beneficial).

description.1: Provide a mechanism to serve content correctly using a recognized encoding method to reduce the payload size of websites and applications. While this means there will be an additional rendering effort on the client-side (decoding the file), the increased speed in loading such files has an PPP benefit that justifies the added effort.
description.2: For machine testability, identifying content encoding methods for file formats can be done by checking the content-encoding headers for various files as they are requested from the server. This can be achieved on an individual basis or through server configuration files. If the content is not being encoded (unless it has been encoded at the source and no further optimization can be made), recommendations can be made to use a compatible compression technique.

examples.1: The [Solid Chocolate Company](https://www.solidchocolates.com/) serves all of their content using GZIP compression headers ensuring that data gets to the user as quickly as possible (in addition to compressing image and media assets at source).

procedure.1: Check all text assets for content-encoding headers to verify compression takes place.
procedure.2: Check content-encoding headers work for not in-use formats for forward-compatibility efforts.
procedure.3: Check if the compression method used is the most optimal type available.

techniques.title: Compress all assets that can be optimized before CMS submission
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [4.3 Compress files where it is beneficial](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#compress-files-where-it-is-beneficial).

description.1: Provide additional mechanisms in place for non-technical users so that the potential for compression is just only checked once files are in place within a website or application's structure (uploaded), but also during the upload process, thereby taking the opportunity to meet sustainability criteria on-the-fly as part of the content management system.
description.2: To pass this success criterion, a CMS (or SaaS) would need to take assets that are uploaded and identify compression that could be applied either by changing file formats or by applying algorithms to it (or both). If improvements can be made, these should replace the original files by default. Machines can verify this is occurring by identifying if the best format is used or if further compression could be applied (this could form part of a tools sustainability rating).

examples.1: Tooling such as [Squoosh](https://squoosh.app/) and [SVGOMG](https://jakearchibald.github.io/svgomg/) can help website creators find optimizations before uploading or submitting content to a product or service (other services offer APIs that can be integrated into tooling).
examples.2: There is a [whole range of plugins available](https://blog.hubspot.com/website/best-wordpress-image-optimization-plugins) for WordPress (and other CMS products) that can assist with automatic image optimization. This can help reduce the environmental impact they have before public visibility.

procedure.1: Check that all assets are optimized for the web in size, format, and quality before publication.
procedure.2: If assets have been altered prior to publication, check users are pre-warned of any changes.
procedure.3: Check that the files published are the optimized versions (more than one may be necessary).
procedure.4: Check if a CMS will be necessary or useful and if so, ensure static assets are uploaded there.

techniques.title: Provide custom error pages to handle unexpected events
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [4.4 Setup necessary error pages and redirection links](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#setup-necessary-error-pages-and-redirection-links).

description.1: Provide a mechanism for if and when users land on a region of your website or application that either does not exist or appears to be broken. Such encounters can be disorientating and without useful signposting and interactions to get users out of such events, additional unnecessary page loads or support requests can occur leading to emissions.
description.2: Machine testing for errors can simply involve triggering the events and identifying if the page loaded in response is one that is server-generated or one that has been customized by the website or application. If it has been customized does it provide useful resources to help resolve the problem? This could be measured using analytics (which may require internal access).

examples.1: HubSpot has [some great examples](https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/33766/10-clever-website-error-messages-from-creative-companies.aspx) of 404 (page not found) error pages showcasing good user experience design in addition to providing a few helpful pieces of advice regarding how they should function.
examples.2: This [GitHub package](https://github.com/HttpErrorPages/HttpErrorPages) provides support for multiple servers and offers a decent boilerplate for anyone wishing to ensure coverage for a wide range of common errors that can occur during site browsing.

procedure.1: Check that the website or application has a custom set of pages to respond to errors.
procedure.2: Check that each error status type has its own page and unique situation handling.
procedure.3: Check that such pages provide signposting to resolve the error they encountered.
procedure.4: Check that existing links to navigation related pages remain fully functional.
procedure.5: Check that links to customer support are provided when solutions do not work.

techniques.title: Resolve all anchor references which trigger errors or redirects
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [4.4 Setup necessary error pages and redirection links](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#setup-necessary-error-pages-and-redirection-links).

description.1: Reduce the amount of wasted rendering effort on the part of users and users of a website or application by ensuring that products and services regularly and routinely check that all of the links within pages are correct and do not need to be updated. This can be a common issue amongst large sites or those with older content (as the material can be moved or disappear online), so links must be updated to reflect this).
description.2: Regarding machine testability, verifying that all links within domains and subdomains of a product or service are correctly linked to and do not resolve in redirect notices or server/missing (not found) errors is essential for meeting this success criterion as it showcases the currency of the content. It should also be noted that links apply equally to images, media, HTML head references, and other materials referenced within the page, not just content anchor links.

examples.1: Open source products like [Link Checker](https://github.com/linkchecker/linkchecker) can verify the status of references across multiple pages. This can be a quick and easy way of locating issues that have built up across an entire product or service.
examples.2: The W3C has a simple [web-based interface](https://validator.w3.org/checklink) for validating links for errors on a page-by-page basis which can be helpful if you do not want to have to install applications or self-host packages to run tests.

procedure.1: Check that no anchor reference or in-page reference contains links that do not resolve (server errors).
procedure.2: Check that no anchor reference or in-page reference contains dead (erroneous) links.
procedure.3: Check that no anchor reference or in-page reference contains redirection links.
procedure.4: Check that links to external websites do not result in forbidden errors.

techniques.title: Check that pages have not been subjected to hijacking
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [4.6 Use automation wisely](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#use-automation-wisely).

description.1: Provide a mechanism for identifying compromised content within a page of a website or application. As having a secure product or service is critical to meeting the societal (people) aspect of PPP and compromised websites can place unnecessary burdens on hardware in certain circumstances, being able to identify and remove such materials is essential.
description.2: Machine testability for these events will require regular monitoring of pages for common features of hijacking events such as critical links suddenly redirecting outside of the primary domain, pages being redesigned with hacking notices, or simply being taken down and replaced with other data. Maintaining a library of established dangerous links, patterns, and features can help flag such issues.

examples.1: [Compromised websites](https://kinsta.com/knowledgebase/the-site-ahead-contains-malware/) may present in many forms, but if they are [detected by Google](https://transparencyreport.google.com/safe-browsing/search), the search giant will intercept the user before they get exposed to the problem code and present them with an error.

procedure.1: Check links do not contain abnormalities such as significant or feature-critical external redirections.
procedure.2: Check pages do not contain tracking, mining, or advertising that has occurred suddenly.
procedure.3: Check pages do not contain closure, ransom, or hacking notices.
procedure.4: Check pages do not trigger sudden redirections to other domains.
procedure.5: Check the domain has not been included within a security firm or Google compromised lists.

techniques.title: Ensure that stored data has a defined and reasonable expiry date
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [4.7 Define the frequency of data refreshes.](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#define-the-frequency-of-data-refreshes).

description.1: Ensure that mechanisms are in place to hold data for only as long as it is required. This will reduce redundancy from things like stale cookies, and it will also assist older devices that may have lower capacity disk space allowances by reducing the overall size of caches which will free up important space (that otherwise reduces performance).
description.2: Identifying technologies for stashing data for a set time such as cookies, local databases, or other methods can be machine-tested. It is also worth identifying techniques that may be slower performing and making recommendations based on such implementations. Otherwise, verify that an expiry date does exist and if time has elapsed (or no date exists), flag the issue.

examples.1: Cookies are a classic example of data stored for a particular reason, but if they are left unchecked, accumulate in vast numbers. While they do not take up a lot of space, they still should be purged if no longer required.

procedure.1: Check the expiration date of locally stored data and if that date has exceeded, remove the data.
procedure.2: Check the expiration date of server-side stored data and if that date has elapsed, remove the information.
procedure.3: If no expiration date exists for client-side or server-side data, either add one or remove the data.

techniques.title: Deliver content using the correct, most secure protocol
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [4.9 Consider the impact and requirements of data processing](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#consider-the-impact-and-requirements-of-data-processing).

description.1: Guarantee that users who experience a website or application will have their experience delivered using a secure delivery route. Transmitting data using non-secure means (now that SSL certificates can be obtained free of charge) should never occur as there are inherent risks that can otherwise be avoided during the browsing session.
description.2: Machine testing for protocol testing will involve examining that the page is being served across HTTPS in opposition to HTTP (there should not be an occasion where both are available, especially if dynamic or interactive content exists). Furthermore, insecure protocols for non-browsing usage should be tested to verify they are disabled and replaced (if required) with more secure options.

examples.1: FTP is a classic example of a protocol that while disabled for browsing in several web browsers, could pose security issues if not blocked entirely. It should instead be replaced with SSH (preferred) or SFTP (at minimum).

procedure.1: Check that the product or service is being delivered over HTTPS rather than HTTP.
procedure.2: Check that alternative protocol usage is only done using secure means.

techniques.title: Provide distributed access to static resources via a CDN
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [4.10 Use Content Delivery Networks (CDNs) appropriately](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#use-content-delivery-networks-cdns-appropriately).

description.1: Offer a mechanism for users to gain access to a static website or application assets in a location that is closer to them than the origin host. By utilizing a content delivery network, large media files, images, fonts, and other static assets can be distributed to regional locations so that users can access them quicker (as the route to the file is shorter).
description.2: Machine testing for content delivery networks should take into account the balance as to whether adding assets to multiple locations (for performance) incurs more of a sustainability cost than loading them quicker. If the value in faster loading is greater, and a CDN is in use, this qualifies as a pass. If no CDN is being used, or one is in use but the added value is neutral or negative, question its impact and whether the material should be instead hosted onsite.

examples.1: While it does not provide insights into sustainability, [CDN Compare](https://cdncomparison.com/) offers a great deal of context between several popular content delivery networks and the offerings they provide to help you make up your mind.

procedure.1: Check the existing location of static resources on the existing website.
procedure.2: If they exist on the first-party domain, calculate the sustainability value of using a CDN.
procedure.3: Check if the value of using a CDN will be beneficial, if so use one.

techniques.title: Ensure that the CDN and its chain of locations are sustainable
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [4.10 Use Content Delivery Networks (CDNs) appropriately](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#use-content-delivery-networks-cdns-appropriately).

description.1: Test the sustainability of the CDN against the WSG as a service provider as a third-party service in addition to any sustainability criteria and best practices that exist externally for infrastructure and hosting. This not only applies to the provider itself but to all of the nodes that it uses to supply distribution, and any third-parties it uses as part of its extended network. As such, calculating and vetting providers can be complex.
description.2: For machine testability, providers should have information about sustainability offered within a sustainability statement along with details of compliance being met plus any sustainability features they provide that enhance their service. If this information is publicly available (and uses recognized sources), it could be parsed by machine, otherwise, a sustainable provider list should be sourced.

examples.1: [Akamai](https://www.akamai.com/resources/research-paper/akamai-2023-environmental-social-governance-report) (PDF) provides a yearly PPP report that showcases and documents all of the changes they have made towards becoming more sustainable. While they have not fully become sustainable, they are getting there.

procedure.1: Check if the CDN provider has a sustainability statement in place.
procedure.2: Check if the CDN provider meets any sustainability compliance obligations.
procedure.3: Check that CDN against the WSG for its sustainability compliance.
procedure.4: Check that the CDN supply network (nodes) are also as sustainable as the provider.

techniques.title: Provide a copy of the product or service close to the user
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [4.10 Use Content Delivery Networks (CDNs) appropriately](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#use-content-delivery-networks-cdns-appropriately).

description.1: Provide a mechanism for mirroring the content (website or application) as close to the user as possible to reduce the loading time as effectively as possible. This can be done using CDNs or by analyzing metrics data and deciding based on the locale of users where the origin host choice would be best placed (both can be useful methods).
description.2: Machine testing for this requires internal access to analytics logs to determine where user locations are and from this identify the best location to place information (if a CDN is used, this may be automatically done on your behalf meeting compliance requirements). If no internal access or data is available, general statistics about Internet usage could help identify trends.

examples.1: [Our World In Data](https://ourworldindata.org/internet), the [World Bank](https://data.worldbank.org/indicator/IT.NET.USER.ZS), and [Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_countries_by_number_of_Internet_users) provide some awesome information on average Internet usage worldwide. While this cannot replace real-world demographics, it can be helpful for new projects.

procedure.1: Check if you only serve a local (single country) audience, if so, avoid CDN usage.
procedure.2: Check using analytics the average distribution of your product or service's users.
procedure.3: Check a hosting or CDN provider's locations to match as closely to your customers.

techniques.title: Avoid hosting dynamic resources or third-party scripts on the CDN
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [4.10 Use Content Delivery Networks (CDNs) appropriately](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#use-content-delivery-networks-cdns-appropriately).

description.1: Prevent non-first-party dynamic resources from being loaded through a content delivery network. The justification behind this is due to browser mechanisms such as CORS and cache partitioning, unfavorable things can occur if you try to load dynamic resources from third-party websites (this is a security measure to prevent malicious code injection).
description.2: As this issue does not affect static resources such as HTML, CSS, or JSON, when testing against the criteria, these types of resources can be excluded. For more dynamic resources like JavaScript or server-side code, if the host URL differs from your own (this includes things like frameworks), flagging up an error and recommending self-hosting or integration with existing tooling should be done.

examples.1: While D3 is a well-respected JavaScript framework for producing graphs and complex charts. [It has a recommendation](https://d3js.org/getting-started) for vanilla HTML users that states a preference for a CDN package (going against our guidelines).
examples.2: [Underscore](https://underscorejs.org/) is another JavaScript framework that offers CDN packages while also offering direct download options. In this case, the download option is provided first (and code examples reflect this) which is good.

procedure.1: Check that your CDN only contains static website assets.
procedure.2: Check that JavaScript on CDNs is first-party hosted only.

techniques.title: Provide a review or expiration date on website content
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [4.12 Store data according to the needs of your users](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#store-data-according-to-the-needs-of-your-users).

description.1: Provide a mechanism that ensures all content within a website or application gets regularly reviewed and if necessary refreshed, updated, or if it has reached the end-of-life, deleted or archived. As such, publicly providing a date when events will occur should offer an incentive for providers to action these labels (and users can note outdated content).
description.2: Machine testability should offer a grace period for content that has passed the date when a review should take place (as circumstances can lead to dates being missed), however, failings should still be flagged as potential issues that need to be resolved. Labels within the content should be detectable by scripts that issue such dates, and if they do not exist, recommendations can be issued.

examples.1: On the [National Health Service](https://www.nhs.uk/conditions/migraine/) website, at the bottom of an article about a medical condition, a clear piece of text mentioning when the content was last reviewed and is next due for review is given.

procedure.1: Check that all articles (or content where material may go out-of-date) have a review or expiration date.

techniques.title: Provide a classification policy to content if it is deemed sustainable
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [4.12 Store data according to the needs of your users](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#store-data-according-to-the-needs-of-your-users).

description.1: Increase findability within content by offering mechanisms within the page for users to filter the results of potential content they are seeking by category, tag, or other variables. How this feature is presented to users can differ between implementations as there are several well-defined patterns, but they can reduce problematic friction in the user experience.
description.2: Machine testability for such features will involve examining the page's source code to identify repeating patterns across several pages (if correctly labeled, patterns such as tags or categories may be semantically easy to find). The sustainability of such implementations must account for the impact it has upon rendering across each page, against the benefit it has to the user experience.

examples.1: A List Apart [provides a topics page](https://alistapart.com/topics/) which groups various pieces of content (articles) into categories. By doing this it reduces the number of pages an individual will need to click through to find what they are after.
examples.2: Maggie Appleton has a [really visually appealing way](https://maggieappleton.com/garden) of laying out all of her different topics, content types, and even how well-developed her thoughts are. With all of this, you can filter her content accordingly.

procedure.1: Check that content within the website (or potentially within long articles) can be filtered by classification.
procedure.2: Check that all classification patterns used on websites are repeated across all pages and clearly labeled.

techniques.title: Ensure that backup providers are classified as sustainable
techniques.applicability: This technique is **Advisory** to meet *success criteria* within [4.12 Store data according to the needs of your users](https://w3c.github.io/sustainableweb-wsg/#store-data-according-to-the-needs-of-your-users).

description.1: Ensure that any third-party backup service provider is examined for sustainability impacts. This will involve examining the impact they have simply in hosting your data, but also how sustainable their platform is, as well as their business. If their model meets any obligations laid out and aligns well against the WSG, it may meet success criteria.
description.2: To identify how sustainable a service is, a list of recommended sustainable backup providers would be an ideal source to utilize (assuming that one exists and it is itself reputable).
